Zevlor: Thank you - we still have the goblins to contend with, but you've given us time to prepare.
Zevlor: I need to ensure my people make the most of it. But here - left over from my soldiering days.
NodeContext: Suddenly industrious, looking forward - but takes a moment to reward us
Zevlor: It's sparse thanks for what you've done for us - and I'm afraid I have more yet to ask.
Zevlor: You've done so much for us - and I have more yet to ask.
Player: Let me guess - you want something.
Zevlor: You've bought us some time here. But the goblins are still massing out there.
Zevlor: We'd need an army of our own to escort us safely to Baldur's Gate, and while I don't doubt your abilities... you're no army.
Zevlor: There may be a way though. Goblins are ill-disciplined - it's unlike them to organise so cleverly.

Zevlor: Somebody must be leading them, bringing discipline to their ranks. Take out that leadership, and they'll scatter.
Zevlor: It's no small thing to ask, but... I've seen you fight. You're equal to the task.
Wyll: By the Triad, there is only one correct answer. Refuse him, and we sentence these people to die.
Player: This isn't my problem.

Havkelaag: Ah, a fellow inhabitor of the Underdark.
Havkelaag: You find yourself in the cradle of all knowledge relating to our subterranean home: the Society of Brilliance.
Havkelaag: Tell me, what can the Society do for you?
Player: I met an expeditioner claiming to work for you. She sought a githyanki egg.
Havkelaag: Yes, dear Lady Esther. One of our most reliable contractors, though unfortunately this particular request was too much even for her.
Havkelaag: I believe she quite lost her senses over the task. She came here insisting I purchase an owlbear egg from her, of all things.
Havkelaag: I don't suppose you've stumbled across any githyanki eggs during your travels? The Society will compensate you for any we purchase, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Havkelaag: Would you consider parting with it? The Society's coffers are deep enough to cover any expenses accrued in its retrieval, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: Chk. Don't you dare consider it.
Player: What are you going to do with it?
Havkelaag: Study it, of course. The githyanki have been a source of great debate in the Society's circles in recent months.
Havkelaag: You are no doubt aware that citizens of the Underdark are held in great suspicion by those who live above ground. Many believe us to be 'evil'.
Havkelaag: The githyanki face similar prejudice, but I believe, if hatched in a less violent, more intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome its evil predispositions.
Havkelaag: I believe that, if hatched in a morally sound, intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome the evil predisposition its githyanki nature bestows.
Player: You assume my people are evil, yet your research is built on sheer superstition.
Havkelaag: Enough of your kind have wreaked destruction on this plane for me to be confident in my assertion.
Havkelaag: When I have a suitable sample for my study, I will, however, prove that the effects of their biological inclination are reversible.
Havkelaag: Once out of the shell, I plan to take a twofold approach:
Havkelaag: The enforced repetition of sound moral principles from the Ptarian code, alongside a series of psionic pulses administered to the cerebral tissue.
Havkelaag: Assuming I can accelerate its growth, I should have conclusive findings within a year or two at the most.
Player: You'd better get cracking, then. Here's the egg.
Player: Sell the egg.

GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: I'm sure a locked door can't stop a brave adventurer like you. But even if you poke the locks or knock-knock-knock, you won't get far without me.
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: Allow me to introduce myself.

: NodeContext: urgent hushing and frantically getting out all of her words as quickly as possible. She's hushing the player, even though she was the one speaking

Yurgir: What's this? Fresh entertainment.
Yurgir: But you're too fresh for this place, aren't you? You've got the stench of the Hells about you - the stench of home. And a whiff of the surface besides.
Yurgir: A servant of Zariel, if I'm not mistaken. I'd know the stench of her infernal machinery anywhere.
Yurgir: You trying to burrow back home, little rabbit?
Player: What do you know about infernal machinery?
Yurgir: Only what I can smell. And whatever engine burns within you is grinding to an inevitable explosion. Burning and fear - you reek with it.
Yurgir: ...There's something else, almost hidden by your fear-stink... cherries, musk... and sulphur.
NodeContext: Sniffing the air at the start, detecting something - then erupting with fury at the end on 'sulphur'.
Yurgir: Raphael! I can smell him all over you. Where is he?!
NodeContext: Furious
Player: Wait - you know Raphael?
Yurgir: That perfumed trickster swindled me - trapped me.
Player: He wants you dead.
Yurgir: Where is he? Spit it out - Now.
Astarion: What are you doing? The devil told us to kill this thing, so let's stop chatting and kill it.
Player: Raphael could be anywhere. But let me go, and I'll free you from his grasp.
Yurgir: Bargaining, are you? A Kara-Tur warlord once tried the same - I made him watch as I ate his concubines and young, then fashioned a codpiece from his skull.
Yurgir: You can't help. It's not just walls that keep me here. Not the traps, the dark or the creatures it hides. Something stronger holds me - a contract.
Yurgir: Either I fulfil the contract, die trying... or forfeit my freedom. If I leave this place now, I'll become Raphael's slave.
Player: Raphael is a devil like all your kind - he deals in tricks. You probably missed a loophole in your contract.
Yurgir: Raphael is no foolish story-devil, his mind is different. Sneaky. Listen...
Yurgir: Spill all the blood sworn to the night.
Silence all prayers; smother each rite.
NodeContext: singing, a cappella
Yurgir: Wander Shar's halls; hungry to slay;
Leave no Justiciar alive to obey.
NodeContext: singing, a cappella
Yurgir: Leave none to hear it, then be set free;
This song is your oath, swear, swear it to me.
NodeContext: singing, a cappella
Narrator: *Well, that explains where all the Dark Justiciars went.*

Yurgir: Oh, I intend to. The lyrics are clear - all who hear the song must die.
Yurgir: Time to die.

Player: There must be something you missed. Let me search this place for you.
Yurgir: I spent a century roaming these halls - I spilled every drop of Dark Justiciar blood that there was to spill. And you think you can do better?

GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: Who am I? It's my favourite question. I scream it into the dark while I sleep, and whisper it to my memories when I wake.
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: I'm the thing that kills you, and the only reason you're alive. Made by a promise, undone by the truth. A handshake, a hug, the first beat of a newborn's heart.

Wulbren Bongle: Good to see you. Wasn't sure you'd make it to the city. Regretting it yet?
Wulbren Bongle: I spent a lot of time thinking of worst case scenarios while I was locked in that cell you plucked me out of at Moonrise.
Wulbren Bongle: I didn't imagine anything as bad as this. The Gondians have handed Enver Gortash the means to bring about the end of liberty in Baldur's Gate.
Wulbren Bongle: And the citizens have rolled out the red carpet for their new tyrant.
Wulbren Bongle: Resistance fighters are few and far between - my Ironhands, what's left of the Harpers, and you. I hope.
Player: I'm with you.
Wulbren Bongle: Good. We don't have a chance unless we stick together - not while the Gondians' metal monsters are patrolling the streets.
Wulbren Bongle: The Steel Watch. They're a threat to you, me - and every man, woman and child in the city.
Wulbren Bongle: They act all civilised... servants of the people. But they only serve one man.
Wulbren Bongle: When he becomes Grand Duke, it will only get worse. Laws will change, freedoms will vanish, and soon you'll be accused and sentenced before you've even committed a crime.
Wulbren Bongle: And the fucking Gondians are to blame for all of it.
Player: Why put the blame on the Gondians?
Wulbren Bongle: They invented the Steel Watchers. And they're building an army of them.
Wulbren Bongle: They've always been happy to provide their technology to despots in exchange for a stipend and the freedom to work in peace.
Wulbren Bongle: They would have licked Sarevok's boots given the chance, and now they'll kiss Gortash's ring while the city screams.
Wulbren Bongle: I had a plan to put a stop to them. But the way things are now, if we stick our heads above ground, the Watchers are on us like flies on shit.
Player: No plan survives contact with the enemy - unless I'm involved.
Wulbren Bongle: Exactly. You freed us from Ketheric's rotten cells - I reckon you can rid us of these Gondians just as easily.
Wulbren Bongle: You just need a little assistance, and I can provide it.
Wulbren Bongle: The Gondians are ingenious. But we're more than equal to them - there's nothing they can build that the Ironhands can't tear down.
Wulbren Bongle: I've built something unique for just that purpose.
Wulbren Bongle: A runepowder bomb - first of its kind. Fifty wizards high on the Weave couldn't summon this kind of firepower.
Wulbren Bongle: Get the bomb inside the Gondian facility, and - boom. Problem solved.
Barcus Wroot: Wulbren, please. This is too far! Everyone in the foundry would be killed.
Wulbren Bongle: Quiet, Barcus. The adults are talking.
Player: Maybe the Gondians are victims, not oppressors.
Wulbren Bongle: The Gondians picked their side the minute they took orders from Gortash.
Wulbren Bongle: If they had any courage, they'd have refused him and died like heroes, spitting in his face.
Wulbren Bongle: Now they'll die like the dogs they are.
Player: This is too messy for me - I'm out.

Vlaakith: They are an agent of the Grand Design. Sent to sabotage the Astral Prism - our last defence against the return of the Illithid Empire.
Vlaakith: As long as they live, the Prism is compromised.
Vlaakith: Find the one inside and destroy them. Be aware - they are not alone, and they will appeal to your trust. They are not to be believed.

Havkelaag: Tell me, what can the Society do for you?
Player: I met an expeditioner claiming to work for you. She sought a githyanki egg.
Havkelaag: Yes, dear Lady Esther. One of our most reliable contractors, though unfortunately this particular request was too much even for her.
Havkelaag: I believe she quite lost her senses over the task. She came here insisting I purchase an owlbear egg from her, of all things.
Havkelaag: I don't suppose you've stumbled across any githyanki eggs during your travels? The Society will compensate you for any we purchase, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Havkelaag: Would you consider parting with it? The Society's coffers are deep enough to cover any expenses accrued in its retrieval, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: Chk. Don't you dare consider it.
Player: What are you going to do with it?
Havkelaag: Study it, of course. The githyanki have been a source of great debate in the Society's circles in recent months.
Havkelaag: You are no doubt aware that citizens of the Underdark are held in great suspicion by those who live above ground. Many believe us to be 'evil'.
Havkelaag: The githyanki face similar prejudice, but I believe, if hatched in a less violent, more intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome its evil predispositions.
Havkelaag: I believe that, if hatched in a morally sound, intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome the evil predisposition its githyanki nature bestows.
Player: So the child inside will be experimented on?
Havkelaag: Once out of the shell, I plan to take a twofold approach:
Havkelaag: The enforced repetition of sound moral principles from the Ptarian code, alongside a series of psionic pulses administered to the cerebral tissue.
Havkelaag: Assuming I can accelerate its growth, I should have conclusive findings within a year or two at the most.
Player: So you, too, follow the teachings of Bahamut. Why him?
Havkelaag: In my years of study, they're the closest I've found to moral perfection. Only under such rigorous 'goodness' will the subject stand a chance of being cured.
Havkelaag: My findings could change the perception of githyanki and the peoples of the Underdark for generations to come.
Player: An experiment like this will only confirm the surface dwellers' suspicion of us.
Havkelaag: Of course it won't. If anything, it will do quite the opposite. The academic institutions up here will finally be forced to take us seriously.
Havkelaag: Now, I'm eager to get started, so will you sell me the egg? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: A gith hatchling is not a lab rat! This shka'keth should be bled dry for the mere suggestion.
Player: Sell the egg.

Lae'zel: Ch'mar, zal'a Vlaakith. You know me.
Vlaakith: Urlon of K'liir speaks most highly. As did Al'chaia before him.
Vlaakith: You seek purity. I may yet grant it.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Vlaakith turns to player and looms over them instead.
Vlaakith: Child of Gith. You carry what is mine. Do I call you loyal servant - or thief?
Vlaakith: Istik. You bear that which is ours. But are you friend, or are you thief?
Player: Neither. It is mine by rights.
Vlaakith: No. It is not 'yours'. To own something is to know it.
Vlaakith: That 'weapon' you carry - the Astral Prism - it is corrupted.
Lae'zel: I will cleanse it for you, my Queen. Tell me how.
Vlaakith: There is someone inside. Their mind is warped, broken - a blight.
Vlaakith: They are an agent of the Grand Design. Sent to sabotage the Astral Prism - our last defence against the return of the Illithid Empire.
Vlaakith: As long as they live, the Prism is compromised.
Vlaakith: Kill them.
Vlaakith: Do this, and I will cleanse you and your allies. Do this -
Vlaakith: - and ascend.
Lae'zel: Ascension? My queen. An honour gained, a burden borne.
Lae'zel: You must accept. Refuse, and you will know my fury.
Vlaakith: Not merely great, Lae'zel. Eternal.
Player: I can't do that. The person inside protects me from the Absolute.
Vlaakith: You are being LIED TO.
Vlaakith: I WILL BE OBEYED!
NodeContext: she loses herself a bit in rage here,
Lae'zel: Tsk'va. Do not defy my queen!
Player: Yes. I will enter the Prism and kill the occupant.

GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: It is so good to see you again! I can't tell you how glad I am that you didn't enter the House without me.
Player: Who are you?
Narrator: *The figure shimmers brightly. Your words seem to have piqued her curiosity.*
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: Who am I? It's my favourite question. I scream it into the dark while I sleep, and whisper it to my memories when I wake.
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: I'm the thing that kills you, and the only reason you're alive. Made by a promise, undone by the truth. A handshake, a hug, the first beat of a newborn's heart.
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: I am Hope. What little is left of her.
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: A GUTTERING CANDLE IN A UNIVERSE OF NIGHT
Karlach: Raphael's driven her mad. Poor soul.
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: I'm not much of a friend to anyone anymore. But I could use a friend myself. Do you want a friend to guide you through this madhouse?
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: Shhhtttt, I hear the jailor, it hears me. It'll call Raphael. Make every question count. Make some of them count twice.
Lae'zel: You must ask of the Orphic Hammer. Without it, the Prince of the Comet - and the githyanki people - remain forever chained.
: NodeContext: urgent hushing and frantically getting out all of her words as quickly as possible. She's hushing the player, even though she was the one speaking
Player: Who's your jailor?
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: The many eyes. The stare of pain. The ray of death. Keep it away. Keep it away.
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: Don't waste any more words, or we'll both be sorry.
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: The House is home to many things. Most will kill you, one can save you. The Hammer - the Hammer that breaks the chains. You must steal it!
Narrator: *You hear a sound like the rattle of a chain, and an agonising scream in your head as Hope flickers from view momentarily.*
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: Shhhhttttt... Quiet... There it goes...
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: Everyone here is mad - even you, especially me - and that makes them dangerous. But it also makes them stupid.
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: I'll make you seem as ruined as the rest of the people here. A simple glamour to make you a terrible wretch.
NodeContext: very enthusiastic, casting a spell to disguise the player
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: Now whisper your questions, little wretch. But really quiet, and very clever. Concentrate.
Player: Formulate your questions using as few words as possible.
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: Remember. Quiet as a mouse.
Player: Where is Raphael?
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: BEHIND YOU
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: Skipping across the planes, spinning plates, making deals with dukes and devils. He's a busy man. A business-man. But not a man at all, of course.
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: He'll be home soon, though, and you better find the Hammer before he arrives.
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: Remember. Quiet as a mouse.
Player: What Hammer are you talking about?
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: THE ONE THAT RAT-A-TATTED THE CHAINS IN PLACE AND BROKE THE FUTURE
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: Discovered an ancient gith prince in need of a saviour? The Orphic Hammer is the perfect tool for breaking all infernal chains.
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: In the Archive. Down the corridor, past the debtors. OH! The debtors. They won't like you.
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: But I like you. I know I do, I think I do, I hope I do. I just need to ask one question, and I'll know for sure.
Player: No. I'm not telling you anything.

Zevlor: Any word on... what we discussed? About Kagha?
Player: I want to discuss something else.
Zevlor: What is it?
Player: I'm looking for a man named Zorru.
Zevlor: You'll find him in camp. What do you want with him?
Player: That is between the two of us.
Zevlor: You'll find him in the caves. But I warn you not to start trouble. There's already enough going.
Zevlor: Whatever your business here, I'd see to it quickly - the druids are forcing everyone out.
Zevlor: This latest attack will only strengthen their resolve.
Player: I have no quarrel with druids.
Zevlor: There have been several attacks by different monsters. The druids blame us 'outsiders' for drawing them here. Nobody's welcome anymore.
Zevlor: They've started a ritual to cut the grove off from the world outside.
Zevlor: We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: What brought you here?
Zevlor: We're refugees from Elturel - we took shelter here after goblins and gnolls attacked us on the road.
Zevlor: We were bound for Baldur's Gate, and it was too late to turn back. Elturel had no place for tieflings after the Descent.
Player: Should've stayed in the Hells - our kind might be treated better there.
Zevlor: Hah - a fair point. We can only hope the citizens of Baldur's Gate are more open-minded.
Zevlor: But we can't get there with those beasts blocking our path.
Zevlor: We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: This ritual - is there no way to convince the druids to stop it?
Zevlor: I've tried. Kagha - their new First Druid - won't see me.
Zevlor: You, though... I know it's not your business, but she owes you for saving this place.
Zevlor: Perhaps you could persuade her. For more time to prepare, if nothing else.
Player: I'm sorry. I've got my own problems.

Benji: *Sniff.* STINKS of CHEESE. *Sniff.* Between his PIGGY TOES.
Montgomery: How dare you! What in the hells is all of this?
Klaus: A necessity, good sir! The Steel Watch loves pretending sweet Rivington doesn't exist.
Klaus: So we have decided to protect you, dear patrons. No need to thank us. You'll be allowed in once I've done this batch - next!
Klaus: Hello, hello, and welcome to the Circus of the Last Days - the finest extraplanar circus there is!
Karlach: Ah! A circus! Can we go?!
Narrator: *This entire place practically vibrates with a familiar, excitable magic. You feel your patron giggle from afar - it's fey magic.*
Player: I never pass up a chance for a bit of faerie mischief - I'd like to enter.
Klaus: Not a problem, dear patron! Benji just has to check if you're a vicious murderer. Benji!
Benji: *Sniff.* Huh. *Sniff.* *SNIFF.*
Benji: Urgh. Smells like a MUD FART.
Klaus: So, doesn't know the meaning of the word soap? Hmm. I don't fancy subjecting our patrons to such a stink.
Klaus: I'm afraid you'll have to move along - no circus for you.
Klaus: That's a first. Usually I'd allow you in, but in these times I can take no chances. Move along - no circus for you.
Narrator: *You feel your patron bristle with a thousand briars at the rejection. It places some barbed words on your tongue - a weapon, should you need it.*
Player: Unless you seek the wrath of the Seelie Court, you will let me pass.

Narrator: *The gnomes speak in soft whispers, the words all but lost in the hot air.*
Player: Eavesdrop on the conversation.
Lunkbug: We'll never get through. We need that smokepowder.
NodeContext: Whispered

NodeContext: Whispered
Lunkbug: Tell the sergeant where she went - Beldron's still trapped with that maniac Nere!
NodeContext: Whispered
Apprentice Laridda: Forget the smokepowder - they'd kill Phil on the spot. I won't let you do it.
NodeContext: Whispered
Player: Listen - I can help you. Act frightened, or you'll draw suspicion.
Lunkbug: Praise Ironhand. Laridda - our prayers are answered!
Lunkbug: Hear me out - our friends are trapped in the cave-in. And I know a way to get them out.
Apprentice Laridda: Bug, please. True Soul Nere will - you know what he'll do.
Player: That sounds like quite the drama. I can't wait to watch.
Apprentice Laridda: What? No. Lunkbug, you can't.
NodeContext: Pleading with Lunkbug not to say anything.
Lunkbug: I've... I've got no choice, Laridda. We have to chance it.
Lunkbug: A few days back, there was a... a scene. Our friend Philomeen, she's a sapper. Set off a blast and ran off.
Lunkbug: We set a spot for hiding if someone found trouble. I'll mark your map.
Lunkbug: If Philomeen made it, you'll find her there. She'll have the stuff to blow that tunnel wide open and get Beldron and the rest out.
Astarion: Well, some explosives would certainly help us free Thulla's friends. They might even survive the blast.
Player: Excellent. I can add Philomeen's head to my collection.

Arron: Refugees, adventurers - no one in years and suddenly we're overwhelmed.
Arron: Well met, and thank you for beating back those goblins. Most brave of you.
Arron: Is there anything you need? Act fast if you do - the ritual will be complete before too long.
Player: I'm looking for a healer.
Arron: I pray no goblin arrow has grazed you!

Player: Are you really locking down the grove?

Alfira: You're here! Good... that's good.
Player: Are you all right?
Alfira: Me? Oh, I'm fine. I'm just worried about the kids. Mol is still missing, and they haven't taken it too well.

Alfira: I've been trying to cheer them up, we're writing a song together. But I think they're just humouring me...
Player: Like I'm humouring you by having this conversation?
Alfira: Well, brainy-breeches, I have a better idea, and I'm so glad you volunteered to help.
Alfira: You and me performing, a private concert - just for the kids. They'd love it, I'm sure!
Alfira: It'd be like a private concert, just for them - they'd love it!
Player: No thanks.

Zevlor: Ngh. Mragreshem.
NodeContext: mrag-RESH-em. Means 'shithead' in infernal. Zevlor has just woken up after being punched in the face by Aradin. He's groggy and pissed off.
Zevlor: A cheap shot. I should've expected that.
NodeContext: Disgust in his voice. His idiot enemy clocked him.
Player: Are you all right?
Zevlor: I'll survive a sore jaw. Particularly if it's rid the grove of Aradin.
Zevlor: Whatever your business, I'd see to it quickly - the druids are forcing everyone out.
Zevlor: This attack will only strengthen their resolve.
Player: Why are they forcing you out?
Zevlor: There have been several attacks by different monsters. The druids blame us 'outsiders' for drawing them here. Nobody's welcome anymore.
Zevlor: They've started a ritual to cut the grove off from the world outside.
Zevlor: We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: What brought you here?
Zevlor: We're refugees from Elturel - we took shelter here after gnolls attacked us on the road.
Zevlor: We were bound for Baldur's Gate, and it was too late to turn back. Elturel had no place for tieflings after the Descent.
Narrator: *You remember it. Elturel and all its citizens were dragged into Avernus - then back out again.*
Player: Let me guess: Your old neighbours called you 'devilkin' and acted like they never knew you.
Zevlor: How easily such a nasty word slips through the mouth of someone you thought you knew.
Zevlor: We thought we'd found sanctuary here, but the druids have determined to turn us out.
Zevlor: We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: What brought you here?

Zevlor: We were bound for Baldur's Gate, and it was too late to turn back. Elturel had no place for tieflings after the Descent.
Narrator: *'The Descent' - an infernal conspiracy that had seen the entire city of Elturel briefly dragged to the Hells.*
Player: Is there a place for tieflings anywhere?
Zevlor: Hah - a fair point. We can only hope the citizens of Baldur's Gate are more open-minded.
Zevlor: But we can't get there with those beasts blocking our path.
Zevlor: We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: This ritual - is there no way to convince the druids to stop it?
Zevlor: I've tried. Kagha - their new First Druid - won't even see me.
Zevlor: You, though... I know it's not your business, but she owes you for saving this place.
Zevlor: Perhaps you could persuade her. For more time to prepare, if nothing else.
Player: I have my own temporal concerns. I need a healer.
Player: Enough about the ritual. I have my own problems.

Nightwarden Minthara: You killed the dead man. I'm impressed.
Nightwarden Minthara: And now your path takes you to Baldur's Gate. I shall walk that path with you.
Player: I hoped you would - we make a good team.
Player: And I'll never tire of killing their previous occupants. We make a good team.
Nightwarden Minthara: My blood ran hot when we broke Ketheric's bones together. But we have greater challenges ahead of us.
Nightwarden Minthara: It is clear, now, that he was not working alone.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Leaves throne, standing from here on
Nightwarden Minthara: During my time in the cult, I came to know one of his co-conspirators all too well - Bhaal's blood-letter, Orin.
Nightwarden Minthara: I know one of them all too well - Bhaal's blood-letter, Orin.
Nightwarden Minthara: To think I thought her to be speaking for the Absolute. I worshipped that woman.
Player: So it's personal? Good - let's take her down.
Nightwarden Minthara: You make it sound so simple. She is the Chosen of Bhaal, Lord of Murder, and one of the cult's founders.
Nightwarden Minthara: Indeed, she is the one who indoctrinated me with the Absolute's lies.
Player: What do you remember of your indoctrination?
Nightwarden Minthara: When I first visited Moonrise, I stood before the Absolute in awe.
Nightwarden Minthara: It was more of an idea than an entity. Pure love. Total power.
Nightwarden Minthara: Orin was by my side. She told me that god had chosen me to be a True Soul. Blessed and adored.
Nightwarden Minthara: Now I know that those memories are lies.
Nightwarden Minthara: There was no god. Orin held me down in a cocoon of flesh, while a mind flayer forced a parasite into my brain. And she laughed at my fear.
Nightwarden Minthara: I will find her, I will murder her. And I will smile.
Player: We'll be heroes - the saviours of Baldur's Gate.
Nightwarden Minthara: Let them think that. There is a short path from saviour to ruler - a short and bloody path. I know it well, and we will walk it together.
Nightwarden Minthara: But Baldur's Gate is a mere bauble. We have the chance to seize something much greater. Surely you see it?
Nightwarden Minthara: In killing Ketheric, we fractured the cult's leadership. When we break the other Chosen and claim their Netherstones, we can take control.
Player: A bold gamble. How can you be sure it's possible?
Nightwarden Minthara: I would have thought this entire conspiracy of gods and monsters to be impossible if I had not seen it for myself.
Nightwarden Minthara: We may fail, but we must try.
Nightwarden Minthara: The power of the enslaved elder brain could reshape the world. We could reshape the world.
Player: The future you propose is shaped by violence. I'd prefer to find another way.
Nightwarden Minthara: There is violence in your future regardless. With me, you can at least be sure the violence will lead to glory.
Nightwarden Minthara: You are not stupid. When we reach Baldur's Gate and face the other Chosen, you will see that my way is the right one.
Player: Maybe I'll change your mind.
Nightwarden Minthara: The elder brain is the only thing that has ever managed to change my mind. You're welcome to try.
Nightwarden Minthara: We are bound, then, to travel together, even if we do not yet agree on our ultimate purpose.
Nightwarden Minthara: There is yet one thing about you that troubles me, though. Something I need you to explain.
Nightwarden Minthara: When we killed the tieflings, at the grove, I was not in control of my actions. You do not have that excuse. So I ask you - why? Why kill them?
Player: I enjoy killing.

Balthazar: Finally, we can talk face-to-face.
Balthazar: Not just any True Soul would have succeeded in following my path through this place. You should be pleased.
Balthazar: I take it the breaking of my skeletons was an accident - the living are so clumsy, after all.
Player: I'm pleased to be of service, Balthazar.
Balthazar: Perhaps you can prove to me that you're more useful alive than dead. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Balthazar: But you're here now, and I may be able to put those limbs to work. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Player: Z'rell said Ketheric wants you to find a relic. That's all I know.
Player: As you mention serving Ketheric, he sent you to find a relic, no?
Balthazar: General Thorm to you. But yes, recovering the relic is the crux of it. He commands, and I, his humble servant, fulfil that command.
Balthazar: While you, an infinitely more humble servant, fulfil my command. I will put you to work - as a scout.
Narrator: *This necromancer has Ketheric's trust. Helping him could be just what you need to gain access to the man himself.*
Player: A scout is little good if they don't know what to look for. What does this relic do?
Player: I need more to go on. Why is this relic so important? What does it do?
Balthazar: Telling you will not make the task any less perilous. Just obey, and use your ignorance as a shield. You should be adept at that already.
Balthazar: The Nightsong lends the General his strength, his invulnerability. It must be recovered, before his enemies attempt to exploit it.
Player: You need my help?
Balthazar: I do not need you, or your help. But you are here in spite of that, so I may as well make use of you.
Balthazar: The relic is close, but the way is barred and Shar's dead are... uncooperative. Clear the path for me - by blade, cunning, or whatever it takes.
Balthazar: I will remain here until you have succeeded, or fallen.
Shadowheart: I'd trust this gasbag about as far as I can throw him - which isn't far. But perhaps better to play along, for now.
Player: You have resources to spare - give me something to aid my search.
Balthazar: Fine. I will assign Flesh to aid you on your way. Ring this bell...
Balthazar: ...and he will come.
Balthazar: My brother is no intellectual powerhouse, but he is strong, loyal and punctual. Should a fight turn against you, remember the bell.
Player: Keep it - this is your problem, not mine.
Balthazar: This is not a problem - it is an opportunity. And it is not a choice either - you will obey.
Player: Fine. I'll see what I can do.
Player: I'll see what I can do.

GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: It is so good to see you again! I can't tell you how glad I am that you didn't enter the House without me.
Player: I didn't have a choice - the door's locked.
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: I'm sure a locked door can't stop a brave adventurer like you. But even if you poke the locks or knock-knock-knock, you won't get far without me.
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: Allow me to introduce myself.
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: I'm the thing that kills you, and the only reason you're alive. Made by a promise, undone by the truth. A handshake, a hug, the first beat of a newborn's heart.
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: I am Hope. What little is left of her.
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: A GUTTERING CANDLE IN A UNIVERSE OF NIGHT
Karlach: Raphael's driven her mad. Poor soul.
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: I'm not much of a friend to anyone anymore. But I could use a friend myself. Do you want a friend to guide you through this madhouse?
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: Shhhtttt, I hear the jailor, it hears me. It'll call Raphael. Make every question count. Make some of them count twice.
Lae'zel: This place must house our contract with Raphael. If Hope points the way, we might take it - and shred it.
: NodeContext: urgent hushing and frantically getting out all of her words as quickly as possible. She's hushing the player, even though she was the one speaking
Player: What is this place?
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: Raphael's House of Hope. But your question was hopeless. You already knew that.
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: Don't waste any more words, or we'll both be sorry.
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: The House is home to many things. Most will kill you, one can save you. The Hammer - the Hammer that breaks the chains. You must steal it!
Narrator: *You hear a sound like the rattle of a chain, and an agonising scream in your head as Hope flickers from view momentarily.*
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: Shhhhttttt... Quiet... There it goes...
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: Everyone here is mad - even you, especially me - and that makes them dangerous. But it also makes them stupid.
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: I'll make you seem as ruined as the rest of the people here. A simple glamour to make you a terrible wretch.
NodeContext: very enthusiastic, casting a spell to disguise the player
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: Now whisper your questions, little wretch. But really quiet, and very clever. Concentrate.
Player: Make your words soft as the assassin's footfall.
Player: Focus on speaking as quietly and calmly as possible.
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: Remember. Quiet as a mouse.
Player: What Hammer are you talking about?
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: THE ONE THAT RAT-A-TATTED THE CHAINS IN PLACE AND BROKE THE FUTURE
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: Discovered an ancient gith prince in need of a saviour? The Orphic Hammer is the perfect tool for breaking all infernal chains.
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: In the Archive. Down the corridor, past the debtors. OH! The debtors. They won't like you.
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: But I like you. I know I do, I think I do, I hope I do. I just need to ask one question, and I'll know for sure.
Player: No. I'm not telling you anything.

He Who Was: The air stirs in trepidation - you have the ledger.
Player: Here - take it.
He Who Was: We have it - her lies, her guilt. Madeline reported her friends to a Dark Justiciar and fled when they were butchered.
He Who Was: Well, she flees no more. I will be the conduit for Madeline's spirit. I will force her to face trial.
He Who Was: And you will be the judge. Make her beg, make her suffer.
Player: When punishment is needed, my hand will not shy from the blade.
He Who Was: The raven was right, we were fated to meet. Break her, my friend - most thoroughly.
He Who Was: Witness her.
NodeContext: low, excited voice. Eyes roll back in his head as he looks up - body jerking. Falls to his knees.
Madeline: You! He said I was gonna be punished, that you'd be the judge. But I didn't mean to hurt anyone!
Player: You 'didn't mean' to kill your friends? How laughable.
Wyll: Not as if you can relate to the killing urge, can you? Hmph - I can taste the hypocrisy from here.
Madeline: I said it didn't mean nothin', that Ben n' Marc were just drunk n' whining.
Madeline: The Dark Justiciar promised she was gonna chat with 'em. She promised.
Player: What did the Dark Justiciar actually do to your friends?
Madeline: She gave 'em a dagger each, and told 'em to press it against their stomachs.
Madeline: On the count of three, to 'start stabbin', and not to stop 'til she said so.
Madeline: She never said stop. I'd do anything to take it back. Anything.
Player: Stab yourself. Rip your stomach open. Feel the pain of your friends - only then will you be free.
Player: Anything? Then hurt yourself as Ben and Marc did - stab yourself.

Liam: N-no! Please! D-don't hurt me!

Balthazar: Ah, the interloper - and in one piece as well. Not an entirely unpromising specimen, for one naturally-born.
NodeContext: Begrudging and largely hostile, but with a hint of appreciation for the player's skill in actually making it this far.
Balthazar: Not just any True Soul would have succeeded in following my path through this place. You should be pleased.
Balthazar: I take it the breaking of my skeletons was an accident - the living are so clumsy, after all.
Player: I'm pleased to be of service, Balthazar.
Balthazar: Perhaps you can prove to me that you're more useful alive than dead. You know what's at stake here, I take it?

Balthazar: You, Z'rell, all the rest... you have only one body with which to serve. I have as many as I care to make.

Balthazar: While you, an infinitely more humble servant, fulfil my command. I will put you to work - as a scout.

Balthazar: The Nightsong lends the General his strength, his invulnerability. It must be recovered, before his enemies attempt to exploit it.
Player: Sounds like you've good reason to be proud of the Nightsong - tell me more.
Balthazar: And spoil the surprise? I think not. But let's just say that the Nightsong was a unique specimen even before I began my work...
Balthazar: Words - even my words - are woefully insufficient. When you see for yourself, you will understand.

Balthazar: I will remain here until you have succeeded, or fallen.

Wulbren Bongle: Good to see you. Wasn't sure you'd make it to the city. Regretting it yet?
Wulbren Bongle: I spent a lot of time thinking of worst case scenarios while I was locked in that cell you plucked me out of at Moonrise.
Wulbren Bongle: I didn't imagine anything as bad as this. The Gondians have handed Enver Gortash the means to bring about the end of liberty in Baldur's Gate.
Wulbren Bongle: And the citizens have rolled out the red carpet for their new tyrant.
Wulbren Bongle: Resistance fighters are few and far between - my Ironhands, what's left of the Harpers, and you. I hope.

Wulbren Bongle: Good. We don't have a chance unless we stick together - not while the Gondians' metal monsters are patrolling the streets.
Wulbren Bongle: The Steel Watch. They're a threat to you, me - and every man, woman and child in the city.
Wulbren Bongle: They act all civilised... servants of the people. But they only serve one man.
Wulbren Bongle: When he becomes Grand Duke, it will only get worse. Laws will change, freedoms will vanish, and soon you'll be accused and sentenced before you've even committed a crime.
Wulbren Bongle: And the fucking Gondians are to blame for all of it.

Arabella: I could hear 'em running behind me. 'Til I couldn't.
Narrator: *You notice the girl shivering in fear and anger. She is not yet ready to hear the truth of her parents' fate.*
Player: I'll think about it. My hands are full with these cultists.
Arabella: Fine. Whatever. I don't need you - I'll find them myself!
Player: You're going to get yourself killed. I'll find them, all right?
Arabella: Thanks so much. I knew you'd help me again!
Arabella: The vines won't last forever. I don't - I don't s'pose I can stay with you?
NodeContext: Slightly unsure of herself.
Arabella: Just 'til you find mum and pops. I won't be any trouble, I swear it!
Player: Forget the search. Your parents are dead.
Arabella: You lie! They're out there. And if you won't find 'em, I will!
NodeContext: Found out her parents are dead. Distraught - her sorcerous powers begin to manifest, intensifying her emotional state.
Player: People die, and that's that. You can stay in my camp, if you quit your blubbering.
Arabella: To the hells with your camp, and to the hells with you.

Nightwarden Minthara: I will never tire of sitting on dead men's thrones.
Player: And I'll never tire of killing their previous occupants. We make a good team.
Nightwarden Minthara: My blood ran hot when we broke Ketheric's bones together. But we have greater challenges ahead of us.
Nightwarden Minthara: It is clear, now, that he was not working alone.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Leaves throne, standing from here on
Nightwarden Minthara: During my time in the cult, I came to know one of his co-conspirators all too well - Bhaal's blood-letter, Orin.
Nightwarden Minthara: I know one of them all too well - Bhaal's blood-letter, Orin.
Nightwarden Minthara: To think I thought her to be speaking for the Absolute. I worshipped that woman.
Player: So it's personal? Good - let's take her down.
Nightwarden Minthara: You make it sound so simple. She is the Chosen of Bhaal, Lord of Murder, and one of the cult's founders.
Nightwarden Minthara: Indeed, she is the one who indoctrinated me with the Absolute's lies.
Player: What can you tell me about Orin?
Nightwarden Minthara: She is fierce, vicious, and cruel. In those respects, we are alike - but she is dangerously unpredictable.
Nightwarden Minthara: If there is a way to turn this design toward slaughter rather than control, she will take it.
Nightwarden Minthara: She is the one who brought me to Moonrise, and into the presence of her so-called god - the Absolute.
Nightwarden Minthara: Now I know that those memories are lies.
Nightwarden Minthara: There was no god. Orin held me down in a cocoon of flesh, while a mind flayer forced a parasite into my brain. And she laughed at my fear.
Nightwarden Minthara: I will find her, I will murder her. And I will smile.
Player: We'll be heroes - the saviours of Baldur's Gate.
Nightwarden Minthara: Let them think that. There is a short path from saviour to ruler - a short and bloody path. I know it well, and we will walk it together.
Nightwarden Minthara: But Baldur's Gate is a mere bauble. We have the chance to seize something much greater. Surely you see it?
Nightwarden Minthara: In killing Ketheric, we fractured the cult's leadership. When we break the other Chosen and claim their Netherstones, we can take control.
Player: Madness. We need to eradicate the cult and the elder brain.
Nightwarden Minthara: Madness would be to let the Absolute's potential go to waste.
Nightwarden Minthara: The power of the enslaved elder brain could reshape the world. We could reshape the world.
Player: I fear we could lose everything if we try to take control.
Nightwarden Minthara: Nothing worthwhile ever came without loss. But together we have the strength to decide who loses. And to make sure it is not us.
Nightwarden Minthara: You are not stupid. When we reach Baldur's Gate and face the other Chosen, you will see that my way is the right one.
Player: Maybe I'll change your mind.
Nightwarden Minthara: The elder brain is the only thing that has ever managed to change my mind. You're welcome to try.
Nightwarden Minthara: We are bound, then, to travel together, even if we do not yet agree on our ultimate purpose.
Nightwarden Minthara: There is yet one thing about you that troubles me, though. Something I need you to explain.
Nightwarden Minthara: When we killed the tieflings, at the grove, I was not in control of my actions. You do not have that excuse. So I ask you - why? Why kill them?
Player: To watch them suffer - I need no other reason than that.

Balthazar: Finally, we can talk face-to-face.
Balthazar: Not just any True Soul would have succeeded in following my path through this place. You should be pleased.
Balthazar: I take it the breaking of my skeletons was an accident - the living are so clumsy, after all.
Player: I'm pleased to be of service, Balthazar.
Balthazar: Perhaps you can prove to me that you're more useful alive than dead. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Balthazar: But you're here now, and I may be able to put those limbs to work. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Player: Z'rell spoke of a relic - something called the Nightsong in your notes. They were very interesting.
Player: Yet you seem no closer to retrieving the Nightsong? I read your notes - very interesting.
Balthazar: Interesting, and private. Give me one reason why I shouldn't have my creations kill you right now, thief.
Player: Touch me, and I'll strike you down with all of nature's fang and fury. Go ahead - try me.
Player: You're hiding from shadows - literally. Don't make threats you can't back up.
Balthazar: ...Fine. I'll forgive your transgressions this time - there are much grander things at stake.
NodeContext: A pause before 'fine' - weighing up the player's fate.
Balthazar: The Nightsong is my finest creation - if I never exceed myself, I will still die happy. Not that I ever intend to do something as gauche as truly dying, of course.
Balthazar: Now, given your prying nature, I have work for you, as a scout.
Balthazar: The Nightsong lends the General his strength, his invulnerability. It must be recovered, before his enemies attempt to exploit it.
Player: Sounds like you've good reason to be proud of the Nightsong - tell me more.
Balthazar: And spoil the surprise? I think not. But let's just say that the Nightsong was a unique specimen even before I began my work...
Balthazar: Words - even my words - are woefully insufficient. When you see for yourself, you will understand.
Player: What do you need me to do?
Balthazar: I do not need you, or your help. But you are here in spite of that, so I may as well make use of you.
Balthazar: The relic is close, but the way is barred and Shar's dead are... uncooperative. Clear the path for me - by blade, cunning, or whatever it takes.
Balthazar: I will remain here until you have succeeded, or fallen.
Shadowheart: I'd trust this gasbag about as far as I can throw him - which isn't far. But perhaps better to play along, for now.
Player: This sounds like your problem, not mine.
Player: Keep it - this is your problem, not mine.
Balthazar: This is not a problem - it is an opportunity. And it is not a choice either - you will obey.
Player: Fine. I'll see what I can do.
Player: I'll see what I can do.

Player: I'm glad you made it too, it's one hell of a curse.
Alfira: It wasn't the curse that did us in.
Alfira: We were ambushed out in the darkness - by cultists. We surrendered, but that wasn't enough for them.
Alfira: They lined us up like dogs. Ikaron was with the kids, telling them it was gonna be all right.

Alfira: Maybe that's why they picked him. Told him to kneel...
Alfira: They took his eyes first. Then his tongue.
Player: Which one was Ikaron again?
Alfira: Which...? He was on the quiet side, but had a heart of gold. Back in the grove, he'd kept an eye on the kids. Gods, that feels like a lifetime ago.
Alfira: Rolan, of all people, saved us.
Alfira: He said he stayed in the grove because of you, and I'm damn glad of it. Without him... well, none of us would be here.
Player: Rolan? The apprentice wizard?
Alfira: Yes. He shielded me and the kids while his brother and sister rushed the cultists.
Alfira: Cal and Lia were dragged away, along with the others. Rolan isn't... taking it so well. None of us, to be honest.
Alfira: How do you do it? How do you keep going?
Player: To linger in the past is to condemn our future. Focus on the here and now.
Alfira: You make it sound so easy - but I'll try.
Alfira: You've done so much for us already, but I have to ask - the others might still be out there.
Alfira: If they're not dead, they're in Moonrise. And gods have mercy on anyone in that hellspit.
Player: I imagine the cultists are torturing them right now.

Angry Mar'hyah: Shut up, Dringo. And get back to work!
Angry Mar'hyah: And you've been slacking as well, Scratch m'boy.
Angry Mar'hyah: This dog is property of Sword Coast Couriers. I'll take him off your hands now.
Player: You shouldn't raise your hand to him like that.
Angry Mar'hyah: I can do whatever I please - he's my dog. Now get out - this is a private yard.
Player: I'm sorry Scratch, there's nothing I can do.

Acolyte Marls: I'm afraid you missed the ship, True Soul.
Acolyte Marls: But there'll be another along soon enough. We're already stacking the cargo.
Player: What cargo?
Acolyte Marls: Nothing of note. Just supplies for the battle ahead - I've already checked it twice over.
Narrator: *As the symbol glows, power courses through you. Authority.*
Player: Think hard. What's really in the boxes?
Narrator: *Something stirs deep within you, hungry and alert... it's taking something you'll never get back.*
Narrator: *As you bear down on his mind, you feel a pulse in response. A thousand pulses, echoing from the nearby crates.*
Narrator: *Tadpoles. His mind had rejected the knowledge, forced it behind a mental wall. A wall you just took a hammer to.*
Acolyte Marls: W-worms. Worms in their heads. Worms all over!
NodeContext: Breathless, near-catatonic with shock
Player: You had best wash them off.
Acolyte Marls: P-parasites! Worms!
NodeContext: Breathy, panicked - you've broken his mind a little

Balthazar: Finally, we can talk face-to-face.
Balthazar: Not just any True Soul would have succeeded in following my path through this place. You should be pleased.
Balthazar: I take it the breaking of my skeletons was an accident - the living are so clumsy, after all.
Player: I'm pleased to be of service, Balthazar.
Balthazar: Perhaps you can prove to me that you're more useful alive than dead. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Balthazar: But you're here now, and I may be able to put those limbs to work. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Player: Judging by how you're cowering in here, your survival?
Balthazar: I do not cower - I plan. I command. I create.
Balthazar: General Thorm trusts me. He knows I will deliver. He knows I will stand by him long after all others wilt and fall.
Balthazar: You and all the rest have only one body with which to serve. I have as many as I care to make.
Balthazar: You, Z'rell, all the rest... you have only one body with which to serve. I have as many as I care to make.
Player: As you mention serving Ketheric, he sent you to find a relic, no?
Balthazar: General Thorm to you. But yes, recovering the relic is the crux of it. He commands, and I, his humble servant, fulfil that command.
Balthazar: While you, an infinitely more humble servant, fulfil my command. I will put you to work - as a scout.
Narrator: *This necromancer has Ketheric's trust. Helping him could be just what you need to gain access to the man himself.*
Player: I need more to go on. Why is this relic so important? What does it do?
Balthazar: Telling you will not make the task any less perilous. Just obey, and use your ignorance as a shield. You should be adept at that already.
Balthazar: The Nightsong lends the General his strength, his invulnerability. It must be recovered, before his enemies attempt to exploit it.
Player: You need my help?
Balthazar: I do not need you, or your help. But you are here in spite of that, so I may as well make use of you.
Balthazar: The Nightsong is close, but the way is barred and Shar's dead are... uncooperative. Clear the path for me - by blade, cunning, or whatever it takes.
Balthazar: I will remain here until you have succeeded, or fallen.
Shadowheart: I'd trust this gasbag about as far as I can throw him - which isn't far. But perhaps better to play along, for now.
Player: This sounds like your problem, not mine.
Player: Keep it - this is your problem, not mine.
Balthazar: This is not a problem - it is an opportunity. And it is not a choice either - you will obey.
Player: Fine. I'll see what I can do.
Player: I'll see what I can do.

He Who Was: The air stirs in trepidation - you have the ledger.
Player: Here - take it.
He Who Was: We have it - her lies, her guilt. Madeline reported her friends to a Dark Justiciar and fled when they were butchered.
He Who Was: Well, she flees no more. I will be the conduit for Madeline's spirit. I will force her to face trial.
He Who Was: And you will be the judge. Make her beg, make her suffer.
Player: When punishment is needed, my hand will not shy from the blade.
He Who Was: The raven was right, we were fated to meet. Break her, my friend - most thoroughly.
He Who Was: Witness her.
NodeContext: low, excited voice. Eyes roll back in his head as he looks up - body jerking. Falls to his knees.
Madeline: You! He said I was gonna be punished, that you'd be the judge. But I didn't mean to hurt anyone!
Player: You 'didn't mean' to kill your friends? How laughable.
Gale: Come now - you're hardly in position to cast judgement on that score, are you?
Madeline: I said it didn't mean nothin', that Ben n' Marc were just drunk n' whining.
Madeline: The Dark Justiciar promised she was gonna chat with 'em. She promised.
Player: What did the Dark Justiciar actually do to your friends?
Madeline: She gave 'em a dagger each, and told 'em to press it against their stomachs.
Madeline: On the count of three, to 'start stabbin', and not to stop 'til she said so.
Madeline: She never said stop. I'd do anything to take it back. Anything.
Player: Stab yourself. Rip your stomach open. Feel the pain of your friends - only then will you be free.
Player: Anything? Then hurt yourself as Ben and Marc did - stab yourself.
Madeline: Like... this?
NodeContext: Madeline draws a blade from behind her and holds it in front of her stomach, blade pointed towards her stomach. She is utterly terrified (pose like seppuku)
Player: Start stabbing, and don't stop until I say so.
Madeline: Ah! I'm sorry.
NodeContext: Ah! is a noise of pain as she stabs herself in the stomach and then pulls out the knife. 'I'm sorry' is said in clear pain.
Madeline: Argh. I'm so sorry.
NodeContext: stabs herself again on 'Argh', noise of pain. I'm so so sorry is half crying as she's in agony.
Player: Did I say stop? Drive the knife in deeper.

Nym Orlith: Couldn't get us off your mind, could you?
Player: Mamzell Amira said you could offer your services as a gift of her thanks.
Sorn Orlith: Or perhaps you have greater ambitions yet.
Sorn Orlith: Trust me, you don't want to miss my signature Menzoberranzan Love Trick.

Sorn Orlith: You'll just have to see what is in store.

Player: I want to hire you, beautiful lad.
Player: I would like to spend time with you, lady Nym.
Gale: I'd prefer you didn't do this. If I'm not enough for you, I could always conjure us some kind of non-sentient companion.
Nym Orlith: If your beloved one wants to join, we could work out something to our mutual satisfaction.
Sorn Orlith: Two of us, two of you. Four gorgeous people.
Player: What an idea!
Nym Orlith: We want both of you, silly! At the same time.
Wyll: No, no. I want romance, not - not debauchery.
Player: You had to spoil the fun, didn't you?

Benji: *Sniff.* STINKS of CHEESE. *Sniff.* Between his PIGGY TOES.
Montgomery: How dare you! What in the hells is all of this?
Klaus: A necessity, good sir! The Steel Watch loves pretending sweet Rivington doesn't exist.
Klaus: So we have decided to protect you, dear patrons. No need to thank us. You'll be allowed in once I've done this batch - next!
Klaus: Hello, hello, and welcome to the Circus of the Last Days - the finest extraplanar circus there is!
Karlach: Ah! A circus! Can we go?!
Narrator: *This entire place practically vibrates with a familiar, excitable magic. You feel your patron giggle from afar - it's fey magic.*
Player: Is this extra security because of the priest who was murdered?
Klaus: Oh, more than him got the knife. They say the Absolute's cronies have been busy chopping people up like it's going out of style.
Klaus: They won't go near us, of course - Lucretious, Bringer of Night, protects us.
Klaus: And even the Absolute knows better than to tangle with a necromancer.
Klaus: Benji here checks all our patrons to make sure none of you are vicious murderers. Can't be too careful!

Klaus: That's a first. Usually I'd allow you in, but in these times I can take no chances. Move along - no circus for you.
Narrator: *You feel your patron bristle with a thousand briars at the rejection. It places some barbed words on your tongue - a weapon, should you need it.*
Player: You can smell the blood of my enemies, that is all. Want to join my scent?
Player: Let me in, or I snap you in two.

Havkelaag: Ah, a surface dweller.
Havkelaag: You find yourself in the cradle of all knowledge relating to the Underdark: the Society of Brilliance.
Havkelaag: Tell me, what can the Society do for you?
Player: I met an expeditioner claiming to work for you. She sought a githyanki egg.
Havkelaag: Yes, dear Lady Esther. One of our most reliable contractors, though unfortunately this particular request was too much even for her.
Havkelaag: I believe she quite lost her senses over the task. She came here insisting I purchase an owlbear egg from her, of all things.
Havkelaag: I don't suppose you've stumbled across any githyanki eggs during your travels? The Society will compensate you for any we purchase, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Havkelaag: Would you consider parting with it? The Society's coffers are deep enough to cover any expenses accrued in its retrieval, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: Chk. Don't you dare consider it.
Player: What are you going to do with it?
Havkelaag: Study it, of course. The githyanki have been a source of great debate in the Society's circles in recent months.
Havkelaag: You yourself have no doubt experienced the prejudice of those who assume that, as beings of the Underdark, we are inherently evil.
Havkelaag: The githyanki face similar prejudice, but I believe, if hatched in a less violent, more intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome its evil predispositions.
Havkelaag: I believe that, if hatched in a morally sound, intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome the evil predisposition its githyanki nature bestows.
Player: What does this 'intellectually stimulating' upbringing look like?
Havkelaag: In the literal sense, I will need to induce the egg to hatch via the application of certain currents to the creature inside.
Havkelaag: Once out of the shell, I plan to take a twofold approach:
Havkelaag: The enforced repetition of sound moral principles from the Ptarian code, alongside a series of psionic pulses administered to the cerebral tissue.
Havkelaag: Assuming I can accelerate its growth, I should have conclusive findings within a year or two at the most.
Player: You'd better get cracking, then. Here's the egg.
Player: Sell the egg.
Havkelaag: Ah. Unfortunately, it seems I've mislaid my purse.
Havkelaag: I don't suppose you'd consider simply donating it to the Society instead?
Player: Fine. Here you go.

Karlach: Could have sworn I told you to piss off. Maybe I imagined it.

Karlach: Anyhow. Piss off.
Player: I met the people looking for you. They say you're a killer - a fiend.
Karlach: And you believe them? Those bastards are trying to feed you a crock of shit.
Karlach: Don't sweat it - devils are tricky fuckers. They can't breathe without lying.
Player: If you're not a fiend, what are you?
Karlach: Are you demented? I'm a tiefling - same as you. More or less.
Karlach: I guess they told you I bite the heads off babies, and paint myself in their blood.
Karlach: Truth's not quite so exciting. Come on over and I'll tell you the whole story.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: ~[reuse]The player approaches Karlach
Karlach: I'm a fugitive - escaped from the Hells, and those bastards are trying to take me back.
Player: You said yourself, devils are tricksters. I don't believe a word of this.
Karlach: You're picking the wrong side here - those bastards aren't what they claim to be.
Narrator: *As she winces, agony shoots through you, as if your bodies share the same wound.*
Narrator: *Then you're lost in visions of demonic armies, as you tear through a landscape of fire and blood.*
Narrator: *The Blood War. You saw it from above as the nautiloid passed through Avernus - this woman was on the frontline.*
Karlach: Ster'ca. What was that? You were inside my head...
NodeContext: ster'ca (stir-KA (very harsh KA)) is a curse word in infernal language. She's shocked, a little afraid of us
Player: It wasn't me - it's the parasites from the mind flayer ship. They connected us.
Karlach: Hold on a minute - you were on that ship? With the tentacles, and the worms?
Karlach: I didn't think anyone else had survived.
Player: You must have got clear of the crash site in a hurry.
Karlach: You're lucky I did.
Karlach: The place would have been crawling with cultists if I'd stuck around - and they'd have dragged us all back to Avernus.
Karlach: And I'll be going straight back if those imp-fuckers catch me.
Player: Why were you in hell in the first place?
Karlach: I was a prisoner, forced to fight in the Blood War - the eternal battle between bad and worse.
Karlach: Most souls in Avernus are just meat for the grinder. But not me.
Karlach: I held my own. More than. Turns out I've got a knack for killing demons - and I enjoy it. That made me a valuable asset.
Karlach: Devils don't like to lose their assets.
Player: Judging by the wound, I'm guessing they already found you.
Karlach: Yeah. Not far from here - gang of cultists cornered me in an abandoned tollhouse.
Karlach: I took out a couple, but I need them all dead.
Player: If I do this, what do I get in return?
Karlach: You get a friend who spat in Baphomet's eye and lived to tell the tale.
Player: I'll do it.

Ptaris: Who are you? Another who needs to learn the difference between right and wrong?

Esther the expeditioner: S_GLO_Expeditioner_5f4048ba-72ef-43c2-9528-1c9a12f3f82f
Narrator: *A githyanki youth, and a familiar one at that. Can it be that this is the one who hatched from the egg you took from the crèche?*
Player: What is this place?
Ptaris: It is my home, of course. Father raised me here. Taught me. Made me grow.
Ptaris: I am Ptaris. And I am good.
Ptaris: Father was bad. They all were. I tried to make them better, but they were not strong enough. They lacked resolve.
Player: What did they do that was so terrible?
Ptaris: They did not live up to father's code. Even he did not follow it correctly.
Ptaris: He was not righteous. He was not innocent. His thoughts were impure.
Ptaris: Such evil can only be cured one way. With pain. With torment. And if that does not work - with death.
Ptaris: Tell me - are you a good person?
Player: Depends on how you define 'good'.
Ptaris: There is only one way. The Ptarian code. Do you follow it?
Ptaris: The Ptarian Code must be obeyed. This is the only way to be sure. Do you follow it?
Player: The code of Bahamut. His guidance leads me in all things.
Ptaris: Do you really believe that? You are unfit to say his name.
Ptaris: I know what you did to me. I see the memory of it, right there in your head.
Ptaris: You stole me from my people. Gave me to that woman. Unhatched, defenceless. You let me be brought here so father could hurt me.
Lae'zel: A githyanki raised in isolation. His blood boils like Vlaakith's, but he knows nothing of the Protocols.
Ptaris: You are bad. You must be taught a lesson.
NodeContext: Like this is the onyl reasonable conclusion
Player: I gave you what my patron gave me - a chance at something more.
Ptaris: You were trying to save me? I - I don't understand.

Vlaakith: Inquisitor W'wargaz was potent. We are impressed.

Player: Wave politely.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: The Inquisitor frowns at your insolence.

Narrator: *Approaching the cells, you're met by hollow-eyed faces. There's an almost physical stink of decay and neglect.*
Player: Astarion - do you know who these prisoners are?
Astarion: I don't even know what this prison is. He hid all of this from me and the others.
Astarion: I'm just surprised to see such wretched-looking specimens - Cazador had a more refined palate than this.
Sebastian: You. I know you.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Astarion frowns and approaches the cell to get a better look at the prisoner who spoke in the previous node. The prisoner steps out of the shadow - he's emaciated, filthy, and dressed in rags that were once finery
Sebastian: You're the one from the tavern. You smiled and joked and got me drunk.
Astarion: You - no. You're dead.
Sebastian: You called me so many sweet things. My name sounded like a lyric on your tongue.
Astarion: Sebastian.
Sebastian: You remember me.
Astarion: You were handsome. Shy. You'd never been kissed.
NodeContext: in shock
Sebastian: You taught me how. And then you destroyed me.
Sebastian: RAGH!
NodeContext: Shout of rage
Astarion: It can't be -
Player: Is this how all of your lovers end up?
Astarion: Don't. Not now.
Astarion: I know so many of these faces.
Astarion: They're my conquests. I pursued them, seduced them, then brought them to Cazador. He told us he was feeding on them.
Astarion: But he turned them to spawn. He turned every last one so he'd have souls for this cursed ritual.
Sebastian: How long?
Astarion: What?
Sebastian: How long have I been down here?
NodeContext: rising anger
Player: Stop whining - the only thing that matters is killing Cazador. He's responsible for all of this.
Sebastian: Kill him? That monster?
Sebastian: You can't. It's not possible...
Player: Where is he now?
Sebastian: The grand chamber, just ahead...
Sebastian: But even if you can kill him - what then? What happens to us?
Player: We'll set you free - what else?
Sebastian: Free from this nightmare? It doesn't feel possible...

Ptaris: I am Ptaris. And I am good.
Ptaris: Father was bad. They all were. I tried to make them better, but they were not strong enough. They lacked resolve.
Player: Who was your father?
Ptaris: Havkelaag. He brought me from the shell. Raised me quickly. Taught me to be good. But he failed me.
Ptaris: He was not righteous. He was not innocent. His thoughts were impure.
Ptaris: Such evil can only be cured one way. With pain. With torment. And if that does not work - with death.
Ptaris: Tell me - are you a good person?

Ptaris: There is only one way. The Ptarian code. Do you follow it?
Ptaris: The Ptarian Code must be obeyed. This is the only way to be sure. Do you follow it?

Ptaris: You are not capable of following its teachings.
Ptaris: I know what you did to me. I see the memory of it, right there in your head.
Ptaris: You stole me from my people. Gave me to that woman. Unhatched, defenceless. You let me be brought here so father could hurt me.

Ptaris: You are bad. You must be taught a lesson.

Player: You would have been destroyed if not for me. I saved you.

Jaheira: There is a grave threat to us all, stretching as far as Baldur's Gate, and I need your help.
Jaheira: The cult of the Absolute is spreading through the city - quietly, quickly, and with unsettling deliberation.
Jaheira: We tracked them to this ancient village only to be faced with a man we killed and buried over a century ago.
Player: Ketheric Thorm. He and I have history.
Jaheira: You were the one who rescued those the Absolute had imprisoned. You were courageous to brave the depths of Ketheric's stronghold.
Jaheira: I suppose you know about Ketheric, then. His invincibility. That we'll never cleanse this place until he's made to bleed.
Jaheira: We met him on the road here - commanding an army of the Absolute, intent on destroying Baldur's Gate. I put an arrow through his eye myself, only to watch him pluck it out like a splinter.
Jaheira: He healed right in front of me, and chased us into the shadows. Things looked hopeless, but experience has taught me that no matter how bleak things look, there's always hope.
Jaheira: You are that hope.

Jaheira: Find out what it is that makes him invincible so we can strip him of his advantage.
Jaheira: Once Ketheric is without his shield, the sword: together we assault his tower, and put a final end to this blight.

Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: My ardents spoke of one of our kin that escaped a crashing ghaik slave-vessel.
Lae'zel: Ch'r'ai. Vlaakith's justice in flesh.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: You have accomplished much, child. I am pleased to finally meet you.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: Interesting. My ardents reported that an istik survived the crashed ghaik slave-vessel.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: You have accomplished much since. I am pleased to finally meet you.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: I heard enough druids died by your hand to make the deity Silvanus himself weep.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: I heard there is so much goblin blood on your hands that it soaks their children's nightmares.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: Kith'rak Voss' made a mistake when he let you go.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: To business. I suspect you plucked something precious from the ghaik ship. Something that belongs to us.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: The weapon. Give it to me.
Narrator: *The artefact stirs in your pocket. Right within your grasp, and desperate not to be relinquished.*
GROUP_Daisy: Don't do it. The weapon is how I protect you.
Lae'zel: Do it. Do not disobey the Inquisitor.
Player: What do I get in return if I give it to you?
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: The ghaik are about to execute their Grand Design and you seek to bargain. P'hak'va.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: The weapon. Now.
Player: I have the weapon - I would say that puts me in a strong position to bargain with you.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: Is that so? Well, then - humour me. What would you ask of an Inquisitor?
NodeContext: Bemused, snarky
Player: On second thoughts, I don't need anything of yours.

GROUP_Daisy: Don't give it to him.
Player: I won't let you take it.

NodeContext: Threatening and confident. She means what she says.
Player: You can't trust him, Lae'zel. Follow my lead. I will choose the right path.
Lae'zel: Tsk - tsk - tsk'va! I hate that you speak the truth.

GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHuman: ...but I think you and I could have a bit of fun together.

GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHuman: Forgive me if I get a bit sharp. My work wears something awful on me.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHuman: You see, I help people from all over Faerûn.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHuman: And you, petal - well, you need a lot of help.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHuman: That wriggler swimming in your brain juice is a bit of an inconvenience, isn't it?

GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHuman: Busybodies are not appreciated around here.
Karlach: I don't like this. What's really going on here?

Karlach: Hold up. One more step, and I put a bolt through your eye.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: stands, holding the crossbow in one hand, her other hand pressed to a wound on the left of her stomach. She appraises the player.
Karlach: No sudden movements, or you're dead.
Karlach: You looking for me?
Player: No, but I see you're hurt - let me help.
Karlach: Hurt or not, I won't miss - lung, heart, arse or eye. Take your pick.
Karlach: Tell me what you're doing here. Now.
Player: I was warned you're dangerous - so am I.
Karlach: If you bite as hard as you bark, we might just get along. I'm dangerous all right, but I've got no quarrel with you.
Karlach: I reckon you've been sold a crock of shit about me.
Karlach: Don't sweat it - devils are tricky fuckers. They can't breathe without lying.
Player: All right, I'm listening - what's really going on here?
Karlach: I guess they told you I bite the heads off babies, and paint myself in their blood.
Karlach: Truth's not quite so exciting. Come on over and I'll tell you the whole story.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: ~[reuse]The player approaches Karlach
Karlach: I'm a fugitive - escaped from the Hells, and those bastards are trying to take me back.
Player: That doesn't sound ideal.
Karlach: It's not - it's a shitting catastrophe. But at least I'm out.
Narrator: *As she winces, agony shoots through you, as if your bodies share the same wound.*
Narrator: *Then you're lost in visions of demonic armies, as you tear through a landscape of fire and blood.*
Narrator: *The Blood War. You saw it from above as the nautiloid passed through Avernus - this woman was on the frontline.*
Karlach: Ster'ca. What was that? You were inside my head...
NodeContext: ster'ca (stir-KA (very harsh KA)) is a curse word in infernal language. She's shocked, a little afraid of us
Player: It wasn't me - it's the parasites from the mind flayer ship. They connected us.
Karlach: Hold on a minute - you were on that ship? With the tentacles, and the worms?
Karlach: I didn't think anyone else had survived.
Player: You must have got clear of the crash site in a hurry.
Karlach: You're lucky I did.
Karlach: The place would have been crawling with cultists if I'd stuck around - and they'd have dragged us all back to Avernus.
Karlach: You gave me some breathing room when you killed those imp-fuckers, but more will come.
Player: Why are you so important to them?
Karlach: Most souls in the Blood War are just meat for the grinder, but not me.
Karlach: Devils don't like to lose their assets.
Player: So you want me to kill the people hunting you?
Karlach: Yeah. Can you handle it?
Player: Yes.

He Who Was: Madeline's spirit is within reach. It is time to make her face trial, to make her suffer.
He Who Was: And you will be the judge. Make her beg, make her suffer.
Player: I'm here to make sure she sees justice.
He Who Was: There is no justice for traitors - only pain.
He Who Was: Witness her.
NodeContext: low, excited voice. Eyes roll back in his head as he looks up - body jerking. Falls to his knees.
Madeline: You! He said I was gonna be punished, that you'd be the judge. But I didn't mean to hurt anyone!
Player: You 'didn't mean' to kill your friends? How laughable.
Shadowheart: Oh, come on now - it happens to the best of us, from time to time.
Madeline: I said it didn't mean nothin', that Ben n' Marc were just drunk n' whining.
Madeline: The Dark Justiciar promised she was gonna chat with 'em. She promised.
Player: If it was drunk complaining, why did you report them?
Madeline: The Dark Justiciar said to report everythin', big or small. She ain't the type you say no to.
Madeline: She gave 'em a dagger each, and told 'em to press it against their stomachs.
Madeline: On the count of three, to 'start stabbin', and not to stop 'til she said so.
Madeline: She never said stop. I'd do anything to take it back. Anything.
Player: Forgiveness comes from within - I cannot gift it to you. But know that I would, if I could.
Player: There's nothing you need do. This wasn't your fault - I promise.

Player: I'm glad you made it too, it's one hell of a curse.
Alfira: It wasn't the curse that did us in.
Alfira: We were ambushed out in the darkness - by cultists. We surrendered, but that wasn't enough for them.
Alfira: They lined us up like dogs. Someone told them to rot in the Nine Hells, that we weren't going anywhere.
Alfira: Maybe that's why they picked him. Told him to kneel...
Alfira: They took his eyes first. Then his tongue.
Player: Which one was Asharak again?
Alfira: Which...? Back in the grove, he ran drills with the kids. Wooden swords and the like. That seems like a lifetime ago now.
Alfira: Rolan, of all people, saved us.
Alfira: He said he stayed in the grove because of you, and I'm damn glad of it. Without him... well, none of us would be here.
Player: I know - Rolan isn't happy with me.
Alfira: Can you blame him? His brother and sister are gone. He's... dealing with it as best he can. We all are.
Alfira: How do you do it? How do you keep going?
Player: Just take it one step at a time.
Alfira: You make it sound so easy - but I'll try.
Alfira: You've done so much for us already, but I have to ask - the others might still be out there.
Alfira: If they're not dead, they're in Moonrise. And gods have mercy on anyone in that hellspit.
Player: I'll do everything in my power to save them - you have my most solemn vow.
