Karlach: Whoa. My engine. It's almost... I don't know. Buzzing. Like it's paying attention.
Narrator: *Your party's prior transgressions are reflected in its stare, as witnessed by the cult's ever-alert scrying eyes.*
Narrator: *It has heard the howls of slaughtered goblins.*
Narrator: *It has seen the deep shadows of Grymforge, and the stone floors left bloodied.*
Narrator: *It knows the cold walls of Moonrise Towers, and the cultists who fell there.*
Narrator: *The Watcher speaks directly into your mind with a voice like poisoned honey.*
GROUP_SteelWatchers: You are marked for special treatment. A defective Steel Watcher. Not simply an enemy of the people, but an enemy of the Absolute. Come quietly, or die.
GROUP_SteelWatchers: You are marked for special treatment. Not simply an enemy of the people, but an enemy of the Absolute. Come quietly, or die.
Player: Consent to arrest.

Wyll: Agh, Hells! I was hoping you wouldn't notice I was gone.
Player: Are you all right?
Wyll: Oh, I'm deeply proud of you. A touch less so of myself.
Wyll: In truth, I don't feel in a festive mood, and didn't want to cast a grey cloud over the night.
Wyll: I'm a devil. I love the people from the grove, but I unsettle them deep down.
Wyll: As I seem to unsettle everyone nowadays.
Wyll: You don't want a devil at your party.
Wyll: Horns this sharp will pop the balloons, you see. And the guests won't take kindly to scars quite so monstrous.
Player: Sorry it has you feeling rough tonight.
Wyll: Ah, I'll be fine. Seeing you has cheered me more than you can know.
Wyll: But off with you. This is your day! Have a dance. Enjoy the music.
Player: Can't you tell why I really followed you out here?
Wyll: Clearly to practice your forest tracking.
NodeContext: Jokingly, and trying to avoid talking about what he knows is obvious
Wyll: I love the way your nose wrinkles up when you get the scent of a lead for the first time.
Wyll: Too much honey-wine can do that. You should watch yourself.
Player: Nope. Guess again.
Wyll: Let me think... Why are you really here?
Wyll: Karlach got lusty at the party, didn't she?
Wyll: She's started a huge fire, and you're trying to save my life.
Wyll: Why else? There couldn't be another reason.
Player: Keep trying!
Wyll: It's a long shot, but - maybe you've grown fond of me. Gods know I've grown fond of you.
Player: Was I that obvious?
Wyll: You have many talents, but subtlety isn't one of them.
Wyll: Well, it just so happens I'm fond of you too.
Wyll: Though I can't say I've earned the honour.
Wyll: I mean - the Blade hasn't exactly lived up to his own reputation.
Wyll: The world spits on those partial to devils. I'm hardly a prime catch.
Player: Maybe a kiss would prove my affections.
Wyll: *Sigh.* You drive a hard bargain. But just the one.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The player and Wyll stoops to share a quick kiss.
Wyll: I - well, then. Erm, you've got a party to get back to. After all, tonight is about you.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We see the Surgeon stand by a table upon which a wriggling human lies strapped down in an X position. Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeon’s voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar.
Malus Thorm: See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy.
Malus Thorm: Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the human’s belly, but it’s a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace.
Malus Thorm: Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver.
Malus Thorm: Come. Step forward. You are no sister, but that matters none. Every student is welcome.
Player: I don't wish to study, only to lift the curse on this land.
Malus Thorm: A curse? Nay, a cure that leads to the very pinnacle of being:
Sister Hunna: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly.
Malus Thorm: It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Astarion: He's just like Cazador - utterly insane.
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being?
Malus Thorm: If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.
Malus Thorm: But you: look how the succour of Shar eludes you. See how painfully present you remain...
Malus Thorm: We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.
Player: Their blades are uneven. Efficient surgery will require further training.
Malus Thorm: Their incisions are, as yet, still streaked with imprecision - that much I must concede.
Malus Thorm: How to steady their hands, I wonder.
Player: Why not have them hone their skills on each other?
Malus Thorm: Yes... For are we not all in need of a cure?
Malus Thorm: The scalpel does not discriminate. Let each and every one of you partake in its soothing journey.
Malus Thorm: Absence, sisters. Acquaint yourselves.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) Screaming and slashing, the sisters brutally murder each other.
Malus Thorm: It is a proud moment when one sees one's teachings so lovingly taken to heart.
Malus Thorm: You are to be commended for their graduation - rewarded with the promised cure.
Malus Thorm: Come, I will acquaint you with the Lady's dark-fingered embrace.
Player: I am not worthy! Please, show me how a master works - I would be honoured.
Player: I would rather acquaint myself - if you show me how.
Malus Thorm: Your diligence is exemplary. Very well: your own scalpel you will be.

Karlach: Hold up. One more step, and I put a bolt through your eye.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: stands, holding the crossbow in one hand, her other hand pressed to a wound on the left of her stomach. She appraises the player.
Karlach: No sudden movements, or you're dead.
Karlach: You looking for me?
Player: No, but I see you're hurt - let me help.
Karlach: Hurt or not, I won't miss - lung, heart, arse or eye. Take your pick.
Karlach: Tell me what you're doing here. Now.
Player: I'm hunting a fiend - you fit the description.
Karlach: Somebody fed you a crock of shit, and you swallowed the lot.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: ~Karlach lowers the crossbow, grimacing in pain
Karlach: Don't sweat it - devils are tricky fuckers. They can't breathe without lying.
Player: All right, I'm listening - what's really going on here?
Karlach: I guess they told you I bite the heads off babies, and paint myself in their blood.
Karlach: Truth's not quite so exciting. Come on over and I'll tell you the whole story.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: ~[reuse]The player approaches Karlach
Karlach: I'm a fugitive - escaped from the Hells, and those bastards are trying to take me back.
Player: You said yourself, devils are tricksters. I don't believe a word of this.
Karlach: You're picking the wrong side here - those bastards aren't what they claim to be.
Narrator: *As she winces, agony shoots through you, as if your bodies share the same wound.*
Narrator: *Then you're lost in visions of demonic armies, as you tear through a landscape of fire and blood.*
Narrator: *The Blood War. You saw it from above as the nautiloid passed through Avernus - this woman was on the frontline.*
Karlach: Ster'ca. What was that? You were inside my head...
NodeContext: ster'ca (stir-KA (very harsh KA)) is a curse word in infernal language. She's shocked, a little afraid of us
Player: It wasn't me - it's the parasites from the mind flayer ship. They connected us.
Karlach: Hold on a minute - you were on that ship? With the tentacles, and the worms?
Karlach: I didn't think anyone else had survived.
Player: I didn't see you aboard. Where were you?
Karlach: I boarded in Avernus - that ship was my way out.
Player: Stowing away aboard a mind flayer's nautiloid? Pretty stupid.
Karlach: If you'd seen as much of hell as I have, you'd rather have a flayer's tentacles up your arse than stay.
Karlach: And I'll be going straight back if those imp-fuckers catch me.
Player: What makes you so important to them?
Karlach: I was a prisoner, forced to fight in the Blood War - the eternal battle between bad and worse.
Karlach: Most souls in Avernus are just meat for the grinder. But not me.
Karlach: I held my own. More than. Turns out I've got a knack for killing demons - and I enjoy it. That made me a valuable asset.
Karlach: Devils don't like to lose their assets.
Player: So you want me to kill the people hunting you?
Karlach: Yeah. Can you handle it?
Player: Yes.

Ptaris: You - you don't look like them. You look like me. Who are you?
Player: I'm [GEN_PlayerName_c11eee1e-7815-6143-7233-f2427799fa53]. Who are you?
Ptaris: I am Ptaris. And I am good.
Ptaris: Father was bad. They all were. I tried to make them better, but they were not strong enough. They lacked resolve.
Player: Don't worry - I'm not here to judge.
Ptaris: Everyone judges, and everyone must be judged. This is the only way to know if we are good enough. Father was not.
Ptaris: He was not righteous. He was not innocent. His thoughts were impure.
Ptaris: Such evil can only be cured one way. With pain. With torment. And if that does not work - with death.
Ptaris: Tell me - are you a good person?
Player: Depends on how you define 'good'.
Ptaris: There is only one way. The Ptarian code. Do you follow it?
Ptaris: The Ptarian Code must be obeyed. This is the only way to be sure. Do you follow it?
Player: What's the Ptarian code?
Ptaris: It is honour. Justice. The true form of goodness we all must live by, decreed by Bahamut himself.
Ptaris: You are not capable of following its teachings.
Ptaris: I know what you did to me. I see the memory of it, right there in your head.
Ptaris: You stole me from my people. Gave me to that woman. Unhatched, defenceless. You let me be brought here so father could hurt me.
Lae'zel: A githyanki raised in isolation. His blood boils like his kin's, but their ways are foreign.
Ptaris: You are bad. You must be taught a lesson.
NodeContext: Like this is the onyl reasonable conclusion
Player: I gave you what my patron gave me - a chance at something more.
Ptaris: You were trying to save me? I - I don't understand.

Araj Oblodra: Welcome back, True Soul.
Araj Oblodra: I'd like to offer my services, if you're willing?
Player: Why are you interested in my pale friend?
Araj Oblodra: Please, you think someone in my line of work wouldn't recognise a vampire spawn when they see one?

Astarion: Don't worry, we're all friends under the Absolute. I won't bite.
Araj Oblodra: Oh I'd prefer if you did.
Araj Oblodra: I assume he belongs to you?
Player: He does what I tell him, if that's what you mean.
Araj Oblodra: As it should be.
Araj Oblodra: Do you have a name, spawn?
Astarion: Astarion, but hold on-
Araj Oblodra: Good. Now, Astarion, I've dreamt of being bitten by a vampire since I was a young girl.
Astarion: I'm sorry? You want to be bitten?
Araj Oblodra: To feel your life's blood slipping away? To dance on the edge between life and death? Yes, I want it.
Araj Oblodra: I'll even compensate you - a potion of legendary power that forever increases the strength of the one who consumes it.
Araj Oblodra: It's not for sale, but it's yours if you bite me.
Astarion: I will have to decline.
Araj Oblodra: Excuse me? This is a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity and you're squandering it.
Astarion: I gave you my answer.
Araj Oblodra: Can't you talk some sense into your obstinate charge?
Player: He said no. There's nothing more to discuss.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We see the Surgeon stand by a table upon which a wriggling human lies strapped down in an X position. Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeon’s voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar.
Malus Thorm: See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy.
Malus Thorm: Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the human’s belly, but it’s a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace.
Malus Thorm: Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver.
Malus Thorm: Come. Step forward. I can see the love of Shar darken your eyes. Be welcome.
Player: May Shar guide your blessing hands.
Malus Thorm: And the rough vessels that are yours.
Malus Thorm: Tell me, what is the guiding principle of the goddess?
Player: Forgetfulness.
Malus Thorm: I profess there is another more profound.
Sister Hunna: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly.
Malus Thorm: It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Shadowheart: A stinging truth - but a truth nonetheless.
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being?
Malus Thorm: If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.
Malus Thorm: But you: look how the succour of Shar eludes you. See how painfully present you remain...
Malus Thorm: We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.
Player: The goddess has greater plans for me than to submit to your scalpels.
Malus Thorm: Another absence is your fate? But if you are not here to be cured, how will my sisters learn?
Malus Thorm: Their incisions are, as yet, still streaked with imprecision - that much I must concede.
Malus Thorm: How to steady their hands, I wonder.
Player: 'Only with sacrifice is mastery gained.' For the sisters to learn, you must submit.
Malus Thorm: Yes. Submit I must, into the Lady's dark-fingered embrace.
Malus Thorm: I see now. By example I must edify and quell the light that blinds us.

Player: I'm glad you made it too, it's one hell of a curse.
Alfira: It wasn't the curse that did us in.
Alfira: We were ambushed out in the darkness - by cultists. We surrendered, but that wasn't enough for them.
Alfira: They lined us up like dogs. Asharak was with the kids, telling them it was gonna be all right.
Alfira: Maybe that's why they picked him. Told him to kneel...
Alfira: They took his eyes first. Then his tongue.
Player: Which one was Asharak again?
Alfira: Which...? Back in the grove, he ran drills with the kids. Wooden swords and the like. That seems like a lifetime ago now.
Alfira: Rolan, of all people, saved us.
Alfira: He said he stayed in the grove because of you, and I'm damn glad of it. Without him... well, none of us would be here.
Player: I know - Rolan isn't happy with me.
Alfira: Can you blame him? His brother and sister are gone. He's... dealing with it as best he can. We all are.
Alfira: How do you do it? How do you keep going?
Player: Danger is my life - there is no greater thrill for me than the hunt.
Alfira: You're made of sterner stuff than me then.
Alfira: You've done so much for us already, but I have to ask - the others might still be out there.
Alfira: If they're not dead, they're in Moonrise. And gods have mercy on anyone in that hellspit.
Player: I'll do everything in my power to save them - you have my most solemn vow.

Ptaris: You - you don't look like them. You look like me. Who are you?
Player: You've never seen another githyanki before?
Ptaris: I am not a githyanki. Do not call me that!
Ptaris: I am Ptaris. And I am good.
Ptaris: Father was bad. They all were. I tried to make them better, but they were not strong enough. They lacked resolve.
Player: So you killed them?
Ptaris: It is not my fault they died. I was only upholding father's code. Even he was not strong enough to follow it.
Ptaris: He was not righteous. He was not innocent. His thoughts were impure.
Ptaris: Such evil can only be cured one way. With pain. With torment. And if that does not work - with death.
Ptaris: Tell me - are you a good person?
Player: I fight, eat, drink, love, and hate with everything I have - that is all that matters.
Ptaris: Such an empty and  meaningless life.
Ptaris: The Ptarian Code must be obeyed. This is the only way to be sure. Do you follow it?
Player: The Ptarian code? Then you follow the teachings of Bahamut?
Ptaris: The purest of your rulers. But you are nothing like him. You are tainted.
Ptaris: I know what you did to me. I see the memory of it, right there in your head.
Ptaris: You stole me from my people. Gave me to that woman. Unhatched, defenceless. You let me be brought here so father could hurt me.
Lae'zel: A githyanki raised in isolation. His blood boils like his kin's, but their ways are foreign.
Ptaris: You are bad. You must be taught a lesson.
NodeContext: Like this is the onyl reasonable conclusion

Player: That's incredibly powerful magic. Why is it so easy for you?
Withers: Because it is my calling. There is little else to explain.
Player: You mentioned a cost - what is it?
Withers: A matter of coin. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Player: At least that's straightforward. I want to resurrect someone.
Withers: Very well. Speak their name and it shall be done.
Withers: Then thou must return with the proper payment.
Player: I want to resurrect [CAMP_Jergal_PlayerToResurrect_1_c85cdca4-6579-776d-206d-6967e4999281].
Withers: This is the price of balance. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Player: Changed my mind. They can stay dead for now.
Withers: Dost thou require anything else?
Withers: Then thou must return with the proper payment.
Player: I want to resurrect [CAMP_Jergal_PlayerToResurrect_1_c85cdca4-6579-776d-206d-6967e4999281].
Withers: This is the price of balance. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Player: Actually, there's something else I need from you.
Withers: Dost thou require a resurrection?
Player: I didn't mean to kill Quil. Please bring her back.
Withers: The bard's death is a weight for thine own conscience to bear.
Withers: She will be left to the peace of eternity, where the Urge shall seek her no more.
Withers: Dost thou require a resurrection?
Player: Where's Arabella gone?
Withers: The girl has left to hew her own path.
Withers: She left you a letter. Thou couldst read it. Or thou couldst not. Such is the way of autonomy.
Withers: Hast thou other business?
Withers: Then thou must return with the proper payment.
Player: I want to resurrect all of my fallen companions. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_2_463b0f43-5410-412d-aba3-875cf81c38ca])
Withers: This is the price of balance. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_2_463b0f43-5410-412d-aba3-875cf81c38ca])
Player: Here's the gold.

Wyll: Agh, Hells! I was hoping you wouldn't notice I was gone.
Player: Of course I noticed. It was no party without you.
Wyll: Really? I'm honoured.
Wyll: In truth, I don't feel in a festive mood, and didn't want to cast a grey cloud over the night.
Wyll: I'm a devil. I love the people from the grove, but I unsettle them deep down.
Wyll: As I seem to unsettle everyone nowadays.
Wyll: You don't want a devil at your party.
Wyll: Horns this sharp will pop the balloons, you see. And the guests won't take kindly to scars quite so monstrous.
Player: To our kind, those features just make you more attractive.
Wyll: You pull them off far more finely than I do.
Wyll: But off with you. This is your day! Have a dance. Enjoy the music.
Player: Can't you tell why I really followed you out here?
Wyll: You must have stumbled out here by complete accident.
Wyll: Too much honey-wine can do that. You should watch yourself.
Player: You're halfway right.
Wyll: Oh! I will safeguard my undergarments with care.
Wyll: Let me think... Why are you really here?
Wyll: You're running away from Gale's cooking.
Wyll: It's delicious, don't get me wrong, but that man wouldn't eat a vegetable unless Mystra herself commanded it.
Wyll: Why else? There couldn't be another reason.
Player: Because I like you. And I want to know you better.
Wyll: Then we share a similar affliction. For I've grown fond of you too.
Wyll: Though I can't say I've earned the honour.
Wyll: I haven't even managed to kill one measly devil. I'm hardly a prime catch.
Wyll: The world spits on those partial to devils. I'm hardly a prime catch.
Player: Maybe a kiss would prove my affections.
Wyll: *Sigh.* You drive a hard bargain. But just the one.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The player and Wyll stoops to share a quick kiss.
Wyll: I - well, then. Erm, you've got a party to get back to. After all, tonight is about you.

Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: My ardents spoke of one of our kin that escaped a crashing ghaik slave-vessel.
Lae'zel: Ch'r'ai. Vlaakith's justice in flesh.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: You have accomplished much, child. I am pleased to finally meet you.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: You have accomplished much since. I am pleased to finally meet you.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: It must not have been easy to escape.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: I heard there is so much goblin blood on your hands that it soaks their children's nightmares.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: You also killed Sarth Baretha. She was formidable.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: To business. I suspect you plucked something precious from the ghaik ship. Something that belongs to us.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: The weapon. Give it to me.
Narrator: *The artefact stirs in your pocket. Right within your grasp, and desperate not to be relinquished.*
GROUP_Daisy: Don't do it. The weapon is how I protect you.
Lae'zel: Do it. Do not disobey the Inquisitor.
Player: Shouldn't you be more concerned with the mind flayer invasion?
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: What makes you think we are not? We are talking about the Grand Design - the restoration of the Illithid Empire. There is nothing of greater importance.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: But the weapon is the solution. I have heard it directly from Queen Vlaakith herself.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: It is how we will stop the mind flayers before they destroy us all.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: Hand it over.
Player: What do I get in return if I give it to you?
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: The ghaik are about to execute their Grand Design and you seek to bargain. P'hak'va.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: The weapon. Now.
Player: Attack.
Lae'zel: Do not try me. Hand over the artefact, or die by my hand.
NodeContext: Threatening and confident. She means what she says.
Player: You can't trust him, Lae'zel. Follow my lead. I will choose the right path.
Lae'zel: Tsk - tsk - tsk'va! I hate that you speak the truth.

Oyster Boy Dringo: Uhh, hi.
Player: Do you work here?
Oyster Boy Dringo: Yeah. I'm caring for the courier dogs. Mar'hyah's my boss.
Oyster Boy Dringo: She's mean. But dad says she'll toughen me up.
Player: The harder you beat a dog, the more it bites back.
Oyster Boy Dringo: That's why I need to work hard in the kennels every day. To get tough.
Angry Mar'hyah: Dringo! Get back to work!
Angry Mar'hyah: And you - what do you want? This is a private yard.
Angry Mar'hyah: You're not a dog. So what the hell are you doing in my kennels?
Player: Woof.
Angry Mar'hyah: Oh gods.
Angry Mar'hyah: Unless you want me to shove you in one of these cages, stop barking and start speaking.
Player: Sorry.
Angry Mar'hyah: It's fine. I have a very robust sense of humour.
Angry Mar'hyah: What do you want?
Angry Mar'hyah: You're not a dog. So what the hell are you doing in my kennels?
Player: Whistle for Scratch.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Dog approaches player
Oyster Boy Dringo: Scratch! It's good to see you boy.
Angry Mar'hyah: Shut up, Dringo. And get back to work!
Angry Mar'hyah: And you've been slacking as well, Scratch m'boy.
Angry Mar'hyah: This dog is property of Sword Coast Couriers. I'll take him off your hands now.
Player: You shouldn't raise your hand to him like that.
Angry Mar'hyah: I can do whatever I please - he's my dog. Now get out - this is a private yard.
Player: This noble beast has tasted true freedom - he will never be brought to heel again.
Angry Mar'hyah: I'm not surprised. Gomwick always indulged him. And he's got a spark in his eye I don't like - looks lively.

Karlach: Could have sworn I told you to piss off. Maybe I imagined it.

Karlach: Anyhow. Piss off.
Player: I met the people looking for you. They say you're a killer - a fiend.
Karlach: And you believe them? Those bastards are trying to feed you a crock of shit.
Karlach: Don't sweat it - devils are tricky fuckers. They can't breathe without lying.
Player: If you're not a fiend, what are you?
Karlach: Are you demented? I'm a tiefling - same as you. More or less.
Karlach: I guess they told you I bite the heads off babies, and paint myself in their blood.
Karlach: Truth's not quite so exciting. Come on over and I'll tell you the whole story.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: ~[reuse]The player approaches Karlach
Karlach: I'm a fugitive - escaped from the Hells, and those bastards are trying to take me back.
Player: You said yourself, devils are tricksters. I don't believe a word of this.
Karlach: You're picking the wrong side here - those bastards aren't what they claim to be.
Narrator: *As she winces, agony shoots through you, as if your bodies share the same wound.*
Narrator: *Then you're lost in visions of demonic armies, as you tear through a landscape of fire and blood.*
Narrator: *The Blood War. You saw it from above as the nautiloid passed through Avernus - this woman was on the frontline.*
Karlach: Ster'ca. What was that? You were inside my head...
NodeContext: ster'ca (stir-KA (very harsh KA)) is a curse word in infernal language. She's shocked, a little afraid of us
Player: That was terrifying.
Karlach: That was one of my good days - the bad ones would knock you sick.
Karlach: Now tell me what you just did to me before I make sure you can never do it again.
Player: It wasn't me - it's the parasites from the mind flayer ship. They connected us.
Karlach: Hold on a minute - you were on that ship? With the tentacles, and the worms?
Karlach: I didn't think anyone else had survived.
Player: Not many did.
Karlach: Poor bastards.
Karlach: I boarded in Avernus - that ship was my way out.
Player: Stowing away aboard a mind flayer's nautiloid? Pretty stupid.
Karlach: If you'd seen as much of hell as I have, you'd rather have a flayer's tentacles up your arse than stay.
Karlach: And I'll be going straight back if those imp-fuckers catch me.
Player: What makes you so important to them?
Karlach: I was a prisoner, forced to fight in the Blood War - the eternal battle between bad and worse.
Karlach: Most souls in Avernus are just meat for the grinder. But not me.
Karlach: I held my own. More than. Turns out I've got a knack for killing demons - and I enjoy it. That made me a valuable asset.
Karlach: Devils don't like to lose their assets.
Player: Judging by the wound, I'm guessing they already found you.
Karlach: Yeah. Not far from here - gang of cultists cornered me in an abandoned tollhouse.
Karlach: I took out a couple, but I need them all dead.
Player: I'll look into it.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Dribbles stands atop the stage, a big smile on his face. Group of children crowded at the front.
GROUP_ACT3_WYR_Circus_RealClown: Buddy the dog is my very best friend. Do you know why?
Quinton: Why?
GROUP_ACT3_WYR_Circus_RealClown: Because with him, anything is paw-sible. Wa-hey!

Lae'zel: Can we not find a more pleasant amusement? Gouging out our own eyeballs, perhaps?
GROUP_ACT3_WYR_Circus_RealClown: Did you hear about the scarecrow who lost a fight?
Player: BOO! GET OFF THE STAGE!
GROUP_ACT3_WYR_Circus_RealClown: You hear that, Buddy? We've got ourselves a Debbie Downer!
Quinton: Booo.
GROUP_ACT3_WYR_Circus_RealClown: Thank you to the loudmouth for volunteering for my next trick! Now, where, oh, where are you...?
NodeContext: Puts his hands to his eyes and dramatically scans the crowd - suddenly locks eyes with the player.
Narrator: *A bloodthirsty rush of fury engulfs you. You want to butcher the crowd, women and children alike, and soak in their innards. It is glorious.*
GROUP_ACT3_WYR_Circus_RealClown: You - my special assistant. Come on up.
Player: This clown's looking at you funny. What's his deal?
Narrator: *Your patron's truesight does not reveal any simple glamours or illusions at play.*
Narrator: *It does, however, pick up something else. The clown's eyes are brimming with evil intent.*
GROUP_ACT3_WYR_Circus_RealClown: Come now, don't be a Cowardly Connie. Perhaps you need a little encouragement?
NodeContext: looks at crowd expectantly, raising his hands to 'give it up' for the player.
GROUP_ACT3_WYR_Circus_RealClown: Now, up, up, double sharp! Or poor Buddy here might think you don't like him.
Player: Approach the stage warily, keeping an eye out.
GROUP_ACT3_WYR_Circus_RealClown: A round of applause for the stalwart heart!
NodeContext: Claps - loudly pleased and encouraging.
Gale: Huzzah! Should this prove embarassing, just imagine the audience in the nude.
GROUP_ACT3_WYR_Circus_RealClown: Now, I always tell children that they're special. That each and every one of them is unique.
GROUP_ACT3_WYR_Circus_RealClown: Tell me - what makes you special?
NodeContext: eager and earnest. Very much like he's talking to a child (he's not, he's talking to the player)
Player: I treat everyone around me with kindness.

Sarevok Anchev: A pleasing thing, to see these stones stained with the blood of he who disgraced my Father.
Sarevok Anchev: A pleasing thing, to see these stones stained with the blood of those who disgraced my Father.
Sarevok Anchev: Our Father.
Sarevok Anchev: I know my like, child of Bhaal - but I needed to see you slaughter, first. To take life and revel in it.
Sarevok Anchev: Are you here to have your vengeance on my granddaughter, Orin?
Sarevok Anchev: But now, you have returned. Tell me, are you here to have your vengeance on my granddaughter?
Player: I've come to slay her. Where is she?
Sarevok Anchev: I see why Orin spoke of you with daggered spite.
Sarevok Anchev: But this is not her dwelling place. Orin resides within our Father's Temple.
Sarevok Anchev: She may have usurped you once, but all her rites and rituals will never match her to your natural gift.
Sarevok Anchev: Bhaal is about to name a new Chosen. All is between you and my granddaughter Orin now, and Orin has much to learn.
Sarevok Anchev: Our lord does not care for beauty. Bhaal cares only for death. Death in numbers. Death in droves.
Sarevok Anchev: It is a lesson Orin will only learn in death. I wonder if you will be the one to teach her?
Player: I shall gladly step aside for Orin. I have no interest in pursuing Bhaal's favour.
Sarevok Anchev: Why do you speak such heresy, child? Bhaal may favour you yet. You are the true inheritor after all.
Sarevok Anchev: I have heard of the duel Orin proposed to you. She seeks to sacrifice you in our Father's temple.
Sarevok Anchev: She dreams that your corpse will be her masterpiece, but she forgets - before your incident, you were the true master.
Sarevok Anchev: You were murder. Pure murder. No excesses. No pretentions.
Sarevok Anchev: I believe you will be the one to slay Orin.
Sarevok Anchev: But you will need my help.
Sarevok Anchev: I see you have not embraced your birthright yet. Perhaps with my stewardship,
Father will bless you yet.
Sarevok Anchev: And when he does, remember grandfather Sarevok. Remember how he helped you. Return to visit him, and tell the blood-drenched tale of your victory.
Sarevok Anchev: Before you may return to our Father's fold, I must first ensure that you remain as pure and worthy of his blessing as you once were.
Sarevok Anchev: Come, child of Murder, let me lead you in Bhaal's worship.
Player: Very well, lead on.
Sarevok Anchev: Spirit of the slaughtered - return to us.
Sarevok Anchev: Show us the achievements this child has accomplished in thy unholy name.
Echo of Amelyssan: His will be done.
[description] NodeContext: Sarevok stands
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Sarevok reaches out his hand, and clenches it as though grasping something tight. He pulls the hand back towards himself, and a roiling, miasma of dark magic streams from off stage into a large cloud in front of the tribunal
[description] CinematicNodeContext: the cloud of dark energy clears. The spectre of our previous victim stands before the player. It is confused, scared, and tries to speak, but no noise escapes.
GROUP_Emperors: Can it be - Belynne herself, reduced to a spectre...
Sarevok Anchev: You took this spirit's life, and thus, its voice. So, speak for it. How was this pitiable creature slain?
Player: I didn't kill this person. But I will kill you.

Karlach: Ah! A circus! Can we go?!
Player: Is now the time for a circus? The army of the Absolute is close.
Klaus: Well, when we zapped in, we didn't know there were religious zealots marching on the city. Slight inconvenience, that. But they're no threat to us.
Klaus: The Absolute's little murderers wouldn't dare.
Klaus: Benji here checks all our patrons to make sure none of you are vicious murderers. Can't be too careful!
Klaus: Hello, hello, and welcome to the Circus of the Last Days - the finest extraplanar circus there is!
Karlach: Ah! A circus! Can we go?!
Narrator: *This entire place practically vibrates with a familiar, excitable magic. You feel your patron giggle from afar - it's fey magic.*
Player: Is this extra security because of the priest who was murdered?
Klaus: Oh, more than him got the knife. They say the Absolute's cronies have been busy chopping people up like it's going out of style.
Klaus: They won't go near us, of course - Lucretious, Bringer of Night, protects us.
Klaus: And even the Absolute knows better than to tangle with a necromancer.
Klaus: Benji here checks all our patrons to make sure none of you are vicious murderers. Can't be too careful!
Klaus: But enough of this - the circus is a place of joy and distraction! So come inside and forget your worries.
Player: All right - I'd like to enter the circus.
Klaus: Not a problem, dear patron! Benji just has to check if you're a vicious murderer. Benji!
Benji: *Sniff.* Huh. *Sniff.* *SNIFF.*
Benji: Urgh. Smells like a MUD FART.
Klaus: So, doesn't know the meaning of the word soap? Hmm. I don't fancy subjecting our patrons to such a stink.
Klaus: I'm afraid you'll have to move along - no circus for you.
Klaus: That's a first. Usually I'd allow you in, but in these times I can take no chances. Move along - no circus for you.
Narrator: *You feel your patron bristle with a thousand briars at the rejection. It places some barbed words on your tongue - a weapon, should you need it.*
Player: I've actually just been hired. I do a magic show.

Karlach: 'The Blade of Frontiers.' That's what you were called before I barrelled into your life and nearly ruined it. And look at you now.
Wyll: An old name, for certain. But a new man to bear it.
Wyll: The four pillars finally rise within me. Courage, Insight, strategy, justice.
Wyll: I'm not to abide them, but to become them.
Wyll: A hero is not just - he is justice. He is not courageous - he is courage.
Wyll: Ah, but enough reflection for today. I'm of a mind to celebrate.
Player: Eh, I'll leave you to it.
Player: What are your plans as the Blade, once the brain is defeated?
Wyll: I do what I do best. Answering the calls of the needful, killing the monsters that haunt them -
Wyll: - and showing them they won't be abandoned.
Player: What are your plans as the Blade, once the brain is defeated?
Wyll: I do what I do best. Answering the calls of the needful, killing the monsters that haunt them -
Wyll: - and showing them they won't be abandoned.
Player: There's more to your plans than you're letting on, isn't there?
Wyll: *Sigh* Yes. There is.
Wyll: I will be hunting Mizora.
Wyll: I won't let her claim one more soul, slay one more victim. I'm going to make my way to the Hells and tear the horns right off her damned head.
Player: Let it go, Wyll. There are better ways to help the people of the Sword Coast.
Wyll: Part of me wants to argue. To insist that I'd be killing Mizora for the good of the Coast.

Crusher: ...thrashed 'is arm with my bare hands. Weaker than pixies, humans.
NodeContext: This goblin is in the  telling a story to the other goblins. We join the conversation in the middle.
Brawler Tiny: Oh ho, you got 'im good!
Crusher: And what're you doin' 'ere with that stink on yer face? Think you can do whatever you want?
Crusher: Think you rule the world, huh?
Crusher: And who're you? 'Nother pest? Everyone just barges in here, thinkin' they rule the world. Hah!
Narrator: *A strange symbol glows, marked on their flesh, and something within you stirs in response.*
Player: I don't just think so; it's a fact. You're nothing but dirt beneath my feet.
Crusher: Well, not us. Things're changin'. We got the Absolute on our side now.
Crusher: Ya better learn yer place.
Crusher: Go on: kiss my foot.
NodeContext: bullying the player, he feels like they won't dare to refuse.
Crusher: Or I'll wipe that nasty look right off yer face.
Wyll: Blech. I'd rather drink the Baldur's Gate sewers dry.
Player: NO. KISS MY FOOT.
Crusher: Errgh... look, mate. Just piss off. You're not welcome 'ere.
NodeContext: We intimidated him, he's trying to shrug us off.
Player: You will obey me. Kneel.
Crusher: I'm sorry, True Soul. I didn't realise.
NodeContext: grovelling. He realised he was talking down to someone of higher status.
Narrator: *A shadow swims across your vision, and a familiar voice tells you to be calm. You are loved.*
Narrator: *His lips smack together wetly and leave a trail of saliva on your foot.*
Crusher: There... there ya go.
NodeContext: grovelling, but he's also disgusted.

Jaheira: Our enemies spread like rub-rot - treat one patch, and two more bloom in its place.
Jaheira: An elder brain, bound by lost Netherese magic, with servants of the Dead Three holding the chain.
Jaheira: Reminds me of old times.
Player: You've tangled with the Dead Three before?
Jaheira: Extensively. Mind flayers too - but I never dreamed of seeing gods and illithids working in consort.
Jaheira: It is most disturbing.
Jaheira: But take courage - we have killed a man who could not die, and stripped the Absolute's army of its general.
Jaheira: You have a Netherstone, and you're on the scent of two more.
Jaheira: These Chosen have reason to fear you - and I would like to be at your side when you confront them.
Player: I'll be glad to have you by my side.
Jaheira: Glad to be there.
Jaheira: Falling foul of Ketheric convinced me that my grand adventures were behind me - that even if I survived, I should hang up my blades.
Jaheira: But you convinced me otherwise.
Jaheira: You ventured into the heart of darkness when I could not.
Jaheira: When we reach Baldur's Gate, there will be even darker paths to tread. I will follow you wherever they lead.
Player: Join me now.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We see the Surgeon stand by a table upon which a wriggling human lies strapped down in an X position. Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeon’s voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar.
Malus Thorm: See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy.
Malus Thorm: Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the human’s belly, but it’s a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace.
Malus Thorm: Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver.
Malus Thorm: Come. Step forward. You are no sister, but that matters none. Every student is welcome.
Player: I am a scholar, this is true - just not in the study of torture.
Malus Thorm: Behold, sisters, the very face of ignorance - one who mistakes tenderness for torture.
Malus Thorm: Go on. Acquaint the face of ignorance with the true object of our studies.
Sister Hunna: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly.
Malus Thorm: It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Shadowheart: A stinging truth - but a truth nonetheless.
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being?
Malus Thorm: If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.
Malus Thorm: You are well on your way. But one white orb disfigures you still. Let us finish the cure.
Malus Thorm: We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We see the Surgeon stand by a table upon which a wriggling human lies strapped down in an X position. Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar.

Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace.
Malus Thorm: Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver.
Malus Thorm: Come. Step forward. You are no sister, but that matters none. Every student is welcome.
Player: You will stop this sick spectacle at once.
Malus Thorm: Sick. Quite. But on the cusp of a cure:
Sister Hunna: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly.
Malus Thorm: It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Wyll: Hells. Only a monster would inflict misery and call it medicine.
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being?

Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.
Malus Thorm: You are well on your way. But one white orb disfigures you still. Let us finish the cure.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We see the Surgeon stand by a table upon which a wriggling human lies strapped down in an X position. Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeon’s voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar.
Malus Thorm: See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy.
Malus Thorm: Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the human’s belly, but it’s a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace.
Malus Thorm: Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver.
Malus Thorm: Come. Step forward. I can see the love of Shar darken your eyes. Be welcome.
Player: May Shar guide your blessing hands.
Malus Thorm: And the rough vessels that are yours.
Malus Thorm: Tell me, what is the guiding principle of the goddess?
Player: Secrecy.
Malus Thorm: I profess there is another more profound.
Sister Hunna: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly.
Malus Thorm: It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Astarion: He's just like Cazador - utterly insane.
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being?
Malus Thorm: If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.
Malus Thorm: But you: look how the succour of Shar eludes you. See how painfully present you remain...
Malus Thorm: We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.

Malus Thorm: How to steady their hands, I wonder.

Malus Thorm: Yes... For are we not all in need of a cure?
Malus Thorm: The scalpel does not discriminate. Let each and every one of you partake in its soothing journey.
Malus Thorm: Absence, sisters. Acquaint yourselves.

Astarion: I know these faces - every one that shares my scar.
Astarion: They're my conquests. I pursued them, seduced them, then brought them to Cazador. He told us he was feeding on them.
Astarion: But he turned them to spawn. He turned every last one so he'd have souls for this cursed ritual.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We see the Surgeon stand by a table upon which a wriggling human lies strapped down in an X position. Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeon’s voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar.
Malus Thorm: See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy.
Malus Thorm: Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the human’s belly, but it’s a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace.
Malus Thorm: Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver.
Malus Thorm: Come. Step forward. You are no sister, but that matters none. Every student is welcome.
Player: In my experience, torture is usually more pain and less proselytising.
Malus Thorm: Behold, sisters, the very face of ignorance - one who mistakes tenderness for torture.
Malus Thorm: Go on. Acquaint the face of ignorance with the true object of our studies.
Sister Hunna: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly.
Malus Thorm: It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Shadowheart: A stinging truth - but a truth nonetheless.
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being?
Malus Thorm: If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.
Malus Thorm: But you: look how the succour of Shar eludes you. See how painfully present you remain...
Malus Thorm: We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.
Player: Their blades are uneven. Efficient surgery will require further training.
Malus Thorm: Their incisions are, as yet, still streaked with imprecision - that much I must concede.
Malus Thorm: How to steady their hands, I wonder.
Player: Sparring is vital to progress. Have them practice on each other.
Player: Why not have them hone their skills on each other?
Malus Thorm: Yes... For are we not all in need of a cure?

[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We see the Surgeon stand by a table upon which a wriggling human lies strapped down in an X position. Malus Thorm: And the rough vessels that are yours.

Sister Hunna: Absence.

Malus Thorm: It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Shadowheart: A stinging truth - but a truth nonetheless.

Lae'zel: My queen.

Narrator: *Hot envy swirls within. Your guts will you to author such cosmic tragedies as she has.*

Player: Wave politely.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Vlaakith, unfazed in the least, considers you with critical interest.

Karlach: Gods, she's gonna rip our legs off.
Vlaakith: To own something is to know it. You know NOTHING of what you carry.
Vlaakith: The Astral Prism - it is corrupted.

Vlaakith: SILENCE, W'wargaz.

Vlaakith: They are an agent of the Grand Design. Sent to sabotage the Astral Prism - our last defence against the return of the Illithid Empire.
Vlaakith: As long as they live, the Prism is compromised.
Vlaakith: Find the one inside and destroy them. Be aware - they are not alone, and they will appeal to your trust. They are not to be believed.

Vlaakith: You are being LIED TO.
Vlaakith: I WILL BE OBEYED!
NodeContext: she loses herself a bit in rage here,

Player: No. In fact, maybe I'll free the one inside.

Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: My ardents spoke of one of our kin that escaped a crashing ghaik slave-vessel.
Lae'zel: Ch'r'ai. Vlaakith's justice in flesh.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: You have accomplished much, child. I am pleased to finally meet you.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: Interesting. My ardents reported that an istik survived the crashed ghaik slave-vessel.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: You have accomplished much since. I am pleased to finally meet you.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: I heard enough druids died by your hand to make the deity Silvanus himself weep.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: I heard there is so much goblin blood on your hands that it soaks their children's nightmares.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: You also killed Sarth Baretha. She was formidable.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: To business. I suspect you plucked something precious from the ghaik ship. Something that belongs to us.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: The weapon. Give it to me.

GROUP_Daisy: Don't do it. The weapon is how I protect you.
Lae'zel: Do it. Do not disobey the Inquisitor.
Player: This weapon - what does it do?

Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: But know that you will have been instrumental in stopping the Grand Design.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: Hand it over.
Player: What do I get in return if I give it to you?
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: The ghaik are about to execute their Grand Design and you seek to bargain. P'hak'va.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: The weapon. Now.
Player: What is the Grand Design?
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: The Grand Design is what all ghaik seek. The restoration of the Illithid Empire, which spanned the entirety of the multiverse.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: For centuries, their elder brains sought to bring back their dominion. Every plot they hatched, we stopped. But now, they are close to succeeding.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: Never before could they pause ceremorphosis. Never before could they let the infection spread undetected.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: This is what we have all been training for.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: You saw the thralls gathered on the ghaik ship.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: It was a vision of the future. Luckily, our queen is here to guide us. She will lead us to victory.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: So. The weapon. Please.
GROUP_Daisy: Don't give it to him.

Lae'zel: Do not try me. Hand over the artefact, or die by my hand.
NodeContext: Threatening and confident. She means what she says.

Lae'zel: Tsk - tsk - tsk'va! I hate that you speak the truth.

Nere: Finally.

Nere: Nere. Does. Not. Fail.
NodeContext: ZHIL loo-NIN! Rising, seething anger. Only the last word should be louder.

NodeContext: Quiet.

Nere: If they are indeed a True Soul, let the Absolute save them.

Nere: You are a traitor.

Nere: Direct your blade at the heretic, duergar. You shall have your coin.
Elder Brithvar: Damn right I'll have it - straight off your rotted corpse.
Nere: Nere is not without mercy, True Soul. The rat has given you a chance to earn my favour.
Nere: Strike him down. Prove your faith.

Angry Mar'hyah: And you've been slacking as well, Scratch m'boy.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: shot of player and whatever remaining gnomes are alive panting, catching their breath. Wulbren appears and claps slowly
Wulbren Bongle: That was a hell of a show, my friend. Watchers collapse in the street as we speak, and the Foundry?
Wulbren Bongle: The scent of runepowder drifts through the city like a warm embrace - I see my bomb did the trick.
Wulbren Bongle: Watchers collapse in the street as we speak. The city thanks you - I thank you.
Wulbren Bongle: But it's not over - so long as a single parasitic Gondian remains, Baldur's Gate is under threat.
Gondian Menalda: Wait - wait! The Banites forced us to make the Steel Watchers, but it's over now. We are his slaves no more.
Gondian Menalda: If you let us go, you will never hear from us again - I swear it.

Wulbren Bongle: Toobin will lie, torment, and scheme until his dying breath. Kill him - or the Ironhands will.
Wulbren Bongle: You Gondians will lie, scheme, and torment this city until your dying breaths. Let's end this.

Barcus Wroot: I thought the Ironhand Gnomes had corrupted you, Wulbren. Now I wonder if it wasn't the other way around.
Barcus Wroot: Kill Toobin, and you kill all we love: Collaboration. Challenge. Solving problems with the power of reason, creativity, and invention.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We see the Surgeon stand by a table upon which a wriggling human lies strapped down in an X position. Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeon’s voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar.
Malus Thorm: See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy.
Malus Thorm: Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the human’s belly, but it’s a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace.
Malus Thorm: Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver.
Malus Thorm: Come. Step forward. You are no sister, but that matters none. Every student is welcome.
Player: In my experience, torture is usually more pain and less proselytising.
Malus Thorm: Behold, sisters, the very face of ignorance - one who mistakes tenderness for torture.
Malus Thorm: Go on. Acquaint the face of ignorance with the true object of our studies.
Sister Hunna: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly.
Malus Thorm: It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Karlach: What the fuck is this loon talking about.
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being?
Malus Thorm: If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.
Malus Thorm: But you: look how the succour of Shar eludes you. See how painfully present you remain...
Malus Thorm: We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.
Player: The sisters aren't ready. They'll make me sick instead of curing me.
Malus Thorm: Their incisions are, as yet, still streaked with imprecision - that much I must concede.
Malus Thorm: How to steady their hands, I wonder.
Player: Sparring is vital to progress. Have them practice on each other.
Player: Why not have them hone their skills on each other?
Malus Thorm: Yes... For are we not all in need of a cure?
Malus Thorm: The scalpel does not discriminate. Let each and every one of you partake in its soothing journey.
Malus Thorm: Absence, sisters. Acquaint yourselves.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) Screaming and slashing, the sisters brutally murder each other.
Malus Thorm: It is a proud moment when one sees one's teachings so lovingly taken to heart.
Malus Thorm: You are to be commended for their graduation - rewarded with the promised cure.
Malus Thorm: Come, I will acquaint you with the Lady's dark-fingered embrace.
Player: I am not worthy! Please, show me how a master works - I would be honoured.
Player: I would rather acquaint myself - if you show me how.
Malus Thorm: Your diligence is exemplary. Very well: your own scalpel you will be.

Jaheira: There is a grave threat to us all, stretching as far as Baldur's Gate, and I need your help.
Jaheira: The cult of the Absolute is spreading through the city - quietly, quickly, and with unsettling deliberation.
Jaheira: We tracked them to this ancient village only to be faced with a man we killed and buried over a century ago.
Player: Ketheric Thorm. He and I have history.
Jaheira: You were the one who rescued those the Absolute had imprisoned. You were courageous to brave the depths of Ketheric's stronghold.
Jaheira: I suppose you know about Ketheric, then. His invincibility. That we'll never cleanse this place until he's made to bleed.
Jaheira: We met him on the road here - commanding an army of the Absolute, intent on destroying Baldur's Gate. I put an arrow through his eye myself, only to watch him pluck it out like a splinter.
Jaheira: He healed right in front of me, and chased us into the shadows. Things looked hopeless, but experience has taught me that no matter how bleak things look, there's always hope.
Jaheira: You are that hope.
Player: It's rare people look at me and see 'hope'.
Jaheira: The light is rather dim, out here in the shadowlands. The point remains:
Jaheira: Protected by your artefact, you can infiltrate his forces at Moonrise Towers, posing as a True Soul.
Jaheira: Find out what it is that makes him invincible so we can strip him of his advantage.
Jaheira: Once Ketheric is without his shield, the sword: together we assault his tower, and put a final end to this blight.
Player: There's something you should know - Marcus, the Flaming Fist upstairs, is a True Soul. He wants to kidnap Isobel.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Jaheir takes the glass from the table.

Jaheira: Is this some kind of test? Or a game, perhaps?

Jaheira: A Harper's gaze can only be turned by proof. By the looks of it, a tall tale is all you have to offer.
Jaheira: It doesn't spoil the taste, if that's what you're wondering.
Player: I prefer using Venian's Breath for interrogations - it doesn't carry a scent.
Jaheira: Not, but it does leave the subject paralysed. Whatever comes after, I would have you standing on your own two feet.

NodeContext: Indifferent to the dead body at his feet.

Wyll: It's funny.
Wyll: As the Blade, I've faced untold brutes and beasts. Together we've seen illithid horrors most souls could merely fathom.
Wyll: I live at the mercy of fiends. A devil's plaything awaiting a future in the Hells.
Wyll: But I've only now come to see who my true enemy's been.

Wyll: Time.

Wyll: It builds mountains and deserts, only to tear them asunder. It fells armies, it conquers kings, queens - even gods.
Wyll: We blink, and we're gone. And our hopes, our memories, our heart-bonds are gone with us.
Wyll: Lucky for us, I've found a way to stop time -
Wyll: If just for a moment.
Wyll: Come, let me show you.

Wyll: The Wilden Oak. Legend has it it's stood since the Age of Dawn.
Wyll: I used to come here and climb it when father's eye was turned elsewhere - daydream of the stories it might tell, if I listened close enough.
Wyll: The dragon lords sparking the skies above it. The moon elves first plucking the strings of the Weave.
Wyll: Standing here, I feel like I can see into forever.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The camera moves from the two of you and outwards. A vista of stunning and quiet beauty.

Wyll: And who I want at my side as it passes.

Wyll: Come, let me show you.
Player: I can't take your hand without hurting you, but I'll follow where you lead.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The scene fades back in. Wyll and the player are near the Chionthar, and walk towards a towering and impressive tree. Acorns are scattered underneath it. It is a beautiful night; the moon and stars shine bright. NOTE: Karlach CANNOT take Wyll's hand, they shouldn't be touching.See N41
Wyll: The Wilden Oak. Legend has it it's stood since the Age of Dawn.
Wyll: I used to come here and climb it when father's eye was turned elsewhere - daydream of the stories it might tell, if I listened close enough.
Wyll: The dragon lords sparking the skies above it. The moon elves first plucking the strings of the Weave.
Wyll: Standing here, I feel like I can see into forever.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The camera moves from the two of you and outwards. A vista of stunning and quiet beauty.
Player: Enjoy the view. Enjoy Wyll's quiet company.
Wyll: I've been thinking a lot about forever. Moreso, I've been thinking everything that comes before -
Wyll: And who I want at my side as it passes.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Wyll kneels to the ground. He takes an acorn and holds it in the palm of his hands, but keeps them close to his body.
Wyll: My mother always said the Wilden Oak's acorns held just a touch of wishing magic.
Wyll: If that be so, then may my greatest wish come true tonight:
Wyll: I love you. Will you be mine - today, and tomorrow, and reaching into eternity?
Player: Take the acorn and nod.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The player takes the acorn from Wyll's hands. He smiles, but remains kneeling.
Narrator: *Your skin flushes and your soul sings as you palm the acorn. Wishing magic, affection, love - whatever the cause, it's as real as the ground beneath you.*
Wyll: Get down here, already. It's time we started our happily-ever-after!
Player: Shit, yes. Let's see the snake this devil's been hiding.

Karlach: 'The Blade of Frontiers.' That's what you were called before I barrelled into your life and nearly ruined it. And look at you now.
Wyll: An old name, for certain. But a new man to bear it.
Wyll: The four pillars finally rise within me. Courage, Insight, strategy, justice.
Wyll: I'm not to abide them, but to become them.
Wyll: A hero is not just - he is justice. He is not courageous - he is courage.
Wyll: Ah, but enough reflection for today. I'm of a mind to celebrate.
Player: Sounds heavenly.
Wyll: Wonderful. You hunt the deer, I'll scrounge up the ale. Prepare your belly for roast a la Blade!
Player: There's more to your plans than you're letting on, isn't there?
Wyll: *Sigh* Yes. There is.
Wyll: I will be hunting Mizora.
Wyll: I won't let her claim one more soul, slay one more victim. I'm going to make my way to the Hells and tear the horns right off her damned head.
Player: Let it go, Wyll. There are better ways to help the people of the Sword Coast.
Wyll: Part of me wants to argue. To insist that I'd be killing Mizora for the good of the Coast.
Wyll: But I can't. Not when I know I'm killing her out of revenge.
Wyll: You're right - I need to forget Mizora. The people of the Coast call to the Blade. I can't let myself stray from them.
Player: What are your plans as the Blade, once the brain is defeated?
Wyll: I do what I do best. Answering the calls of the needful, killing the monsters that haunt them -
Wyll: - and showing them they won't be abandoned.
Player: What are your plans as the Blade, once the brain is defeated?
Wyll: I scout both the Hells and the Coast's havens. And I destroy every fiend that dares put its eye on Faerûn.
Player: What are your plans as the Blade, once the brain is defeated? What about us?
Wyll: I love the Coast, I love its people. The Blade of Avernus will toil for them...
Wyll: ... but he'd rather not toil alone.
Wyll: Faerûn doesn't need just one hero. It needs two. Say you'll fight with me.
Player: Nothing would make me happier.

Duke Ulder Ravengard: The Absolute's voice is gone, but I still hear its echoes - reflections of reflections.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: As you wish.
Player: Florrick is free. She's gathering allies as we speak.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Tremendous news. She proves as loyal to you as she is to me.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: I couldn't bear it if she died by my command. May the Triad guide her steps.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: As you wish.
Player: Tell him about your battle with Ansur.
Wyll: I failed, father. The wyrm is fallen.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: A terrible fate for Ansur, my son. Yet my hopes for the city's future have never been higher.
Wyll: I don't understand.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: You and your allies slayed the undead terror that was once the great Ansur. You are stronger than even the great wyrm.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: You will be the one to part the storms and lead the people through. You, not Ansur, are the saviour we need.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: First, you will fell the Absolute. Then, we will rebuild Baldur's Gate, we will take back our city - together.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: I will name you Baldur's Gate's newest Grand Duke of the Council. You will be hailed Heart of the Gate.
Wyll: Grand Duke? I look the part of a fiend.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: I will tell the citizens and the patriars of your good works. They will know you carry your father's banner.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: But it is true - you are still under the she-devil's thumb...
Narrator: *Uncertainty fills the air. Wyll has reached a fork in his path. In which direction will he travel?*
Player: A Grand Duke? You can't turn down an offer like that. Think of the power you'll wield.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Wyll?
Wyll: They're right and we both know it. No manner of duke should be tied to a devil's leash.
Wyll: No manner of duke should save a city, only to open a gate to the Hells.
Wyll: There will be no Grand Duke Wyll Ravengard. And there will be no Blade of Frontiers.
Wyll: I am now the Blade of Avernus.
Wyll: For as long as demons and devils imperil the Sword Coast, they will be my prey.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Then go with my blessing. Be Faerûn's great defender.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Courage. Insight. Strategy. Justice. Let these be the lights that guide you, my son. Hail the Blade of Avernus!
Minsc: The Blade of Avernus!
Narrator: *A calm settles over you. The elder brain is a menace - but with the Blade of Avernus at your side, you know you can triumph.*

[description] CinematicNodeContext: The player approaches Wyll. Wyll is practing his dance moves, oblivious to the player's presence, lost in his reverie.
Player: Nice form. Where'd you learn to dance like that?
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Wyll does a few more turns and steps, than faces the player and smiles.
Wyll: I've attended my share of fancy balls and masquerades. A few elegant moves can turn all the right heads.
Wyll: Figured it was time to brush up on my skills. I wouldn't want to fail my new partner.
Wyll: I need them to be just right. I wouldn't want to fail my new partner.
Player: A new partner? And who might that be?
Wyll: As luck would have it, they just arrived.
Wyll: May I have this dance?
Player: I'd like to, but I'm afraid I'll trip over my own feet.
Wyll: Don't worry. It's not really about the dance. It's about who's we're dancing with.
Wyll: But I count you as a friend. My closest, in all honesty. Please - dance with me. If we must burn with the Hells' fires, let us burn together.
Player: I'm ready - let's dance.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Player smiles and bows, taking Wyll's hand. Wyll turns guiding the player into the the center of the imaginary dance floor he was using to practice at the start of the scene.

Wyll releases the player's hand, and the two assume courtly posture oppsite eachother.

Wyll releases the player's hand, and the two assume courtly posture oppsite eachother.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Wyll stomps, assuming a paso doble stance. Perfect lines. Intense. He takes a few rhythmic steps foward, playfully invading the player's space while maintaining eye contact.
Player: Gather your strength and leap into the air.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Player leaps into the air, but then stumbles, rights themselves, and smiles at Wyll.
Wyll: Ha ha - ahem. Don't you worry. It takes years to master the Vollante.
Player: Well, not all of us were born with silver spoons in our mouths.
Wyll: Fair enough. Perhaps a less energetic style would suit you better.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Wyll begins a slower dance and the player follows suit.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The players come closer together until their lips are a hair away of touching.
Player: Press your lips against Wyll's.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The player kisses Wyll, then pulls away.
Wyll: So much shadow around us. To think I almost missed the light.
Wyll: Well - it's getting late. We can't face the morrow if we don't bid farewell to the now.
Player: I was hoping we might spend the night... together.
Wyll: I'm tempted, trust me. I thought my heart might burst with every step.
Wyll: But I still keep faith in the old tales of love, the once-upon-a-times and the happily-ever-afters.
Wyll: I'd like to do this the proper way. The way of the old romances sung by the bards.
Wyll: Till next time, good night - and dream sweetly.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Wyll enters camp. A diabolical circle draws itself onto the ground in front of Wyll, and Mizora in devil form rises from it.
Mizora: Sorores surge. Testis esto pacti mei.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Two more diabolical circles form, and a female devil rises from each.
Narrator: *You've heard of such devils - Sisters of Justice, adjudicators of diabolical contracts and bargains.*
Karlach: Holy fucking hells.
Wyll: Enough games - my father is dead. There must be something you can do.
Arbiter Cirrus: Infernus contractus te vocamus. Infernus contractus te vocamus. Infernus contractus te vocamus.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: A contract appears in the air, glowing. It is Wyll's contract.
Wyll: Then break it already. I suffered enough.
Mizora: No contract is ended without sacrifice. A cost must be paid.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Flames ignite Mizora and her two companions. Mizora's voice echos outward as if amplified by the Hells themselves.
Mizora: Wyll Ravengard. A choice is before you.
Mizora: Option one. I show you the way to your father. I guarantee him no harm except that from you and your allies. And you pledge your soul to me and the archdevil Zariel in a pact eternal.
Mizora: Option two. I break your pact. You are freed from your duty but retain your devil form. Your father dies by his enemy's hand.
Mizora: Name your sacrifice.
Karlach: Bloody Zariel. I won't let her take Wyll!
Wyll: Mizora, you arsehole.
Mizora: Choose.
Player: Save your father, Wyll. The city will need him to help rebuild.

Mizora: I come to bargain. The Hells demand witness.

Mizora: How else? We bargain.

Dror Ragzlin: Shuugaan, a shuulkac. O taash okec dor.
Dror Ragzlin: I command you, corpse: speak! Reveal truth to the Absolute!
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Camera focuses on mind flayer corpse, which doesn't move.[Custom cameras required]
Lae'zel: By Vlaakith's blade. A ghaik.
NodeContext: For Lae'zel: Ghaik = GAYK.
Dror Ragzlin: Nothing. Must be reading it wrong!
Dror Ragzlin: Shuugaan, a shuulkac...
Wyll: This is the big boss. Strike him down.
Narrator: *The hobgoblin turns to you, and the parasite squirms in your skull.*
Dror Ragzlin: A gith...
Narrator: *You taste the ale on his tongue and the bile in his soul.*
Narrator: *The visions cloud your inner eye for a brief moment once again. You see the hobgoblin, bowing before the armoured elf you'd glimpsed before.*
InternalNodeContext: Referring to a glimpse of Dror with Ketheric, one of the dead tribunal. This narrator node will ultimately be replaced or complimented by cinematics, once the necessary assets are available. This elaborates on a vision experienced during the 'Voice of Absolute' scene, which occurs before this on entering the goblin camp.
Narrator: *The elf speaks of the hunt for a great weapon, and the rewards that will go to whoever finds it. The hobgoblin's eyes gleam hungrily.*
Dror Ragzlin: Well, look here. A True Soul halfling. A long way from home, aren't you?
Narrator: *He doesn't speak his next words, yet they still rattle your skull from within.*
Dror Ragzlin: You ever talk to a dead squid? Now's your chance.
InternalNodeContext: Sound effect: He is talking telepathically.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Staging transition.
Player: Turn away from the rite.
Narrator: *Your skull sizzles with Ragzlin's displeasure. His mouth is still, yet you hear his demand.*
Dror Ragzlin: I speak for the Absolute. And I say you stay.
Player: Study the mind flayer. Could it be...?
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The camera should examine the mind flayer corpse. [Custom camera]
Narrator: *You feel Shadowheart's anxiety. The weapon the Absolute seeks - it's the artefact that she carries. The same one that protected you as you entered the goblin camp.*
Narrator: *Her mind focuses - their suspicion cannot be aroused. They cannot discover that the weapon they seek is within their grasp.*
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The other companions share looks with each other - they've all picked up on Shadowheart's warning. Tav realises Dror is waiting for them.
Player: Study the corpse. Was this the mind flayer that tortured you?
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The camera should examine the mind flayer corpse. [Custom camera]
Narrator: *This mind flayer's build is smaller, its garb plainer - a fearsome creature even in death, but not the one that tormented you.*
Narrator: *Yet it, too, roamed the nautiloid. It would have seen you, known you...*
Player: Attack the hobgoblin.

NodeContext: Addressed to the room in general

Wyll: Counsellor Florrick - are you all right?
Counsellor Florrick: Wyll, by the living gods! I couldn't have asked for a finer saviour.
Counsellor Florrick: A scorched throat, a few hairs singed off. Nothing a bit of time and fresh air can't cure.
Counsellor Florrick: Fist Ito, a new duty calls. Drow have taken Grand Duke Ulder Ravengard - westward, if my eyes and ears can be believed.
Counsellor Florrick: Report to the manip and send for reinforcements. We must find the Duke.
Wyll: No, it can't be. You mean, they've taken -
Counsellor Florrick: Yes, Wyll. The drow have your father.
Player: Ravengard? I know that name.
Counsellor Florrick: As well you should. He is the great champion of the Council, commander of the Flaming Fist - the binding force holding Baldur's Gate together.
Counsellor Florrick: Without him, the city faces collapse. In fact, I fear that may have been the intention of those who abducted him.
Counsellor Florrick: Wyll, you must hold little love for your father. But please, find him and return him to the city.
Wyll: Trust us to see it through, Counsellor.
Counsellor Florrick: May I trust you'll see it through?
Player: Goblins take their prisoners to Moonrise Towers. That's where we'll find the duke.
Counsellor Florrick: Moonrise Towers? Along the old road? That place is cursed. Few could survive there...
Counsellor Florrick: ... unless darker forces are at work.
Counsellor Florrick: This was no random attack. The Grand Duke was their target.
Player: On my oath: I will see Duke Ravengard rescued, and his captors vanquished.
Player: I'll search for Duke Ravengard.

Wyll: It's funny.
Wyll: As the Blade, I've faced untold brutes and beasts. Together we've seen illithid horrors most souls could merely fathom.
Wyll: I live at the mercy of fiends. A devil's plaything awaiting a future in the Hells.
Wyll: But I've only now come to see who my true enemy's been.
Player: The elder brain?
Wyll: Maybe. But I think the right answer is much simpler than that:
Wyll: Time.
Wyll: Time is so gods-damned greedy. It can never give, only take.
Wyll: It builds mountains and deserts, only to tear them asunder. It fells armies, it conquers kings, queens - even gods.
Wyll: We blink, and we're gone. And our hopes, our memories, our heart-bonds are gone with us.
Wyll: It even comes for your people in the astral sea. Time may hunt slowly - but it still hunts.
Wyll: Lucky for us, I've found a way to stop it -
Wyll: If just for a moment.
Wyll: Come, let me show you.
Player: We've got big problems to solve, Wyll. Maybe later.
Wyll: A toll of the bell - it's all I ask. Our problems can wait that long.
Player: I couldn't have said it better. Let's go.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The player takes Wyll's right hand with their left. Wyll smiles and the scene fades out.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The scene fades back in. Wyll and the player are near the Chionthar, and walk towards a towering and impressive tree. Acorns are scattered underneath it. It is a beautiful night; the moon and stars shine bright.
Wyll: The Wilden Oak. Legend has it it's stood since the Age of Dawn.
Wyll: I used to come here and climb it when father's eye was turned elsewhere - daydream of the stories it might tell, if I listened close enough.
Wyll: The dragon lords sparking the skies above it. The moon elves first plucking the strings of the Weave.
Wyll: Standing here, I feel like I can see into forever.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The camera moves from the two of you and outwards. A vista of stunning and quiet beauty.
Player: A beautiful story. I'm glad you told it to me.
Wyll: I was hoping you'd think so.
Wyll: I've been thinking a lot about forever. Moreso, I've been thinking everything that comes before -
Wyll: And who I want at my side as it passes.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Wyll kneels to the ground. He takes an acorn and holds it in the palm of his hands, but keeps them close to his body.
Wyll: My mother always said the Wilden Oak's acorns held just a touch of wishing magic.
Wyll: If that be so, then may my greatest wish come true tonight:
Wyll: I love you. Will you be mine - today, and tomorrow, and reaching into eternity?
Player: Yes, yes, yes!
Wyll: Gods. You've made me the happiest soul in all the Realms.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The player takes the acorn from Wyll's hands. He smiles, but remains kneeling.
Narrator: *Your skin flushes and your soul sings as you palm the acorn. Wishing magic, affection, love - whatever the cause, it's as real as the ground beneath you.*
Wyll: Get down here, already. It's time we started our happily-ever-after!
Player: Shit, yes. Let's see the snake this devil's been hiding.
